results.event_name: ‘The Berenstain Bears Live! In Family Matters, the Musical’
results.web_description: The most famous bears since the three in the Goldilocks story are now onstage in this adaptation of three of the titles in the long-running children’s book series by Stan and Jan Berenstain. The show, by Michael Borton and Michael Slade, offers a pleasant hour for small theatergoers, with a pop-flavored score and actors who inhabit their fuzzy roles enthusiastically. But like the books, it’s rather tame and tidy; after this many years of a formula, even the Berenstain cubs are starting to show their age (:55).
results.cross_street: between Broadway and Central Park West

results.web_description: And the beat goes on (and on), with percussion unlimited (1:30).
results.street_address: Second Avenue at Eighth Street, East Village
results.cross_street: between Seventh Street and St. Marks Place

results.web_description: The hue of blue is immediately recognizable, as are the characters, thanks to the ubiquity that comes with commercials, “The Tonight Show,” Las Vegas and the like. But before all that, there was the show: conceptual art as entertainment (1:45).

“The Music of the Night” and the fantastical staging — and that chandelier! — remain since the 1988 opening of this Andrew Lloyd Webber musical. The show, as Frank Rich described it in 1988, is a highly romanticized “beast-meets-beauty, loses-beauty story” set in Paris (2:30).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Dec. 28 and Jan. 4)

results.web_description: Big hair, thrashing guitars and inspired humor augment dreams of rock stardom in this jukebox musical, which transferred to Broadway in 2009 with the songs of ’80s acts like Journey, Pat Benatar, Bon Jovi, Starship, REO Speedwagon and Poison (2:25).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 18 (no performances on Thanksgiving, with an added show on Nov. 26)

results.web_description: Jazz Age sex, murder and razzle-dazzle heat up this dance-fueled musical, revived on Broadway in 1996 and continuing since with an eclectic, ever-changing selection of Roxies, Velmas and Billy Flynns (2:25).
This biomusical that walks like a man tells the story of Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons. The Tony-winning show has been a fixture on Broadway since 2005 (2:30).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving and Christmas Eve)

results.web_description: The director Julie Taymor’s puppet- and spectacle-filled take on Disney’s call of the wild, based on the 1994 animated film and a standard on Broadway since 1997, with a score by Elton John and Tim Rice (2:45).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Year's Eve and New Year's Day, with added shows on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Before the 2008 Meryl Streep film, there was the stage version: This jukebox musical set to the music of Abba opened on Broadway in 2001 and recounts a young girl’s search for three possible fathers, all past paramours of her mother, Donna of the onetime Donna and the Dynamos (2:20).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 25, Dec. 23 and 30)

results.web_description: Try to remember, if you can, this show’s first Off Broadway performance, back in 1960. No? If not — and whether you have or haven’t seen the many incarnations of this classic around the nation, from high schools and colleges, to community theaters and regional productions — there’s still an Off Broadway cast regularly offering “Try to Remember” and the many other songs from this canonical American musical, in which boy meets girl, forever (2:05).

A “Sesame Street” for confused young adults, with R-rated puppets giving lively life lessons amid the human cast. This 2003 musical has traveled from Off Broadway to a Tony-winning Broadway run and back to an Off Broadway house, with its wit and sex intact (2:15).
The tear-jerker story of these trailblazing African-American pilots (2:30).
Did the psychiatrist do it? This small-scale murder mystery has been running in New York since 1987 (1:30).

Punchdrunk, a British site-specific theater company, has taken over three abandoned warehouses to enact the sorry sights of the murderous Macbeths’ career as a movable orgy. The result suggests what might have happened if Stanley Kubrick (of “The Shining”) had designed the Haunted Mansion at Disney World (2:00).

One of the most popular Broadway shows since its 2003 opening — and featuring the song “Defying Gravity,” which you’ve no doubt heard in countless renditions — this musical revisionist view of Oz, focusing on Glinda the Good Witch and her rival, the Wicked (or is she?) Witch Elphaba, champions the misunderstood young woman in a spectacle directed by Joe Mantello (2:45).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: This delightful collaboration between the creators of “South Park” (Trey Parker and Matt Stone) and the composer of “Avenue Q” (Robert Lopez) is blasphemous, scurrilous and as pure-hearted as a Rodgers and Hammerstein show. No musical has so successfully had it both ways since “The Producers.” Casey Nicholaw is the witty co-director (with Mr. Parker) and choreographer (2:15).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve, Christmas and New Year's Day, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.event_name: ‘Archaeology Zone: Discovering Treasures From Playgrounds to Palaces’
results.web_description: Children will step into the shoes of an explorer like Indiana Jones in this permanent exhibition at the Jewish Museum, but the adventures will be purely scholarly. Still, there is plenty of excitement in analyzing artifacts like a jar handle, a clay jug and a bangle and figuring out the purpose behind ancient pieces like a Greek helmet and a bull-shaped vessel. This interactive show, for ages 3 to 10, also includes a recreated room from the Ottoman period (about 1900), where young archaeologists can dress in costume.
results.price: free with admission: $15; $12 for 65+; $7.50 for students; free for 18 and under and members; pay what you wish on Thursdays from 5 to 8 p.m.
results.date_time_description: Exhibition is open all days except Wednesdays and Saturdays, from 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., and till 8 p.m. on Thursdays; until 4 p.m. on Fridays.

results.event_name: ‘The Gazillion Bubble Show: The Next Generation’
results.web_description: Children love bubbles, and this interactive show promises not just a gazillion but also some of the largest ever blown, along with light effects and lasers. The stars are the members of the Yang family: Fan and Ana Yang and their son Deni and others, who rotate as M.C.’s for the production. Audience members may even find themselves in bubbles of their own.
results.price: $55 to $75; lap seats for ages 2 and under are $20, cash only, at the box office. V.I.P. seats, including a toy and other perks, are $99.50
results.date_time_description: Fridays at 7 p.m.; Saturdays at 11 a.m. and  2 and 4:30 p.m.; Sundays at noon and 3 p.m. Additional shows during some weeks, including on Dec. 11 and 18 at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m.

results.event_name: Union Square: Crossroads of New York
results.web_description: Sponsored by the Union Square Partnership, this free year-round tour focuses on the area’s political and social histories. This walk, led by guides from Big Onion Walking Tours, meets at 2 p.m. by the statue of Lincoln in Union Square Park, near the 16th Street transverse.

results.event_name: ‘The Berenstain Bears Live! In Family Matters, the Musical’
results.web_description: The most famous bears since the three in the Goldilocks story are now onstage in this adaptation of three of the titles in the long-running children’s book series by Stan and Jan Berenstain. The show, by Michael Borton and Michael Slade, offers a pleasant hour for small theatergoers, with a pop-flavored score and actors who inhabit their fuzzy roles enthusiastically. But like the books, it’s rather tame and tidy; after this many years of a formula, even the Berenstain cubs are starting to show their age.
results.cross_street: between Columbus Avenue and Central Park West
results.price: $34.95 to $59.95 (The most expensive tickets include wearable bear ears and foot-of-the-stage seating.)
results.date_time_description: Saturdays at 11 a.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m.

results.web_description: That’s Tina deVaron, a jazz musician and singer, whose musical brunch for young people at the Measure Lounge at Langham Place, Fifth Avenue, a hotel in Midtown Manhattan, has returned for another season. Ms. deVaron, who often sings show tunes for children, also improvises and gears her performances to the audience. This month’s theme is Holiday Hit Parade, with carols and seasonal classics, as well as a dessert of cookies to decorate and eat.
results.venue_name: Measure Lounge, Langham Place, Fifth Avenue
results.price: $40 a person, including food; $20 for 3 and younger

results.web_description: Max Darwin, a.k.a. the Amazing Max, may come across like the M.C. at a raucous bar mitzvah party, but he does know his craft. In this hourlong magic performance, revived for the holiday season, he performs feats like mind reading, making objects disappear and then reappear in unexpected places, and sending coins raining from various parts of the body. The show, which has been updated, includes lots of audience participation.
results.cross_street: between Amsterdam and West End Avenues
results.price: $29.50 to $49.50; premium seats, at $64.50, include 25-minute preshow access to the Magic Lounge, where children will have a magic lesson and receive a magic trick to take home
results.date_time_description: Nov. 28-Dec. 31 at various times; Dec. 6 and 7 at 1 p.m.

results.event_name: ‘The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe’
results.web_description: If the children of the Pevensie family could travel to the magical land of Narnia through something as simple as a wardrobe, why shouldn’t two hard-working actors be able to play them and all the characters found there? That’s what Abigail Taylor-Sansom and her husband, Rockford Sansom, are attempting in the Off Broadway Family Theater’s first production, le Clanché du Rand’s adaptation of C. S. Lewis’s classic novel. (The run is open-ended.)

The script is obvious, covering virtually every issue that might touch the lives of black women, but Dorothy Marcic’s good-natured, low-budget musical is all about the songs. From “Ain’t Nobody’s Business if I Do” to “Single Ladies,” you could do a lot worse (1:30).

results.event_name: ‘Seven in One Blow, or the Brave Little Kid’
results.web_description: In the Grimm fairy tale “The Brave Little Tailor,” the title character dispatches seven flies with one swat but allows the gullible public to believe that he has really whacked seven enemies. In its annual holiday production for ages 4 and older, written and directed by Randy Sharp, Axis Theater has adapted the story to feature a clever New York boy. He triumphs over adversity, thanks to his wits and a lot of help from theatergoers, who are asked to shout lines and even sing.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 5-21. Fridays at 7 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays at 3 p.m.

results.web_description: Prokofiev’s classic may seem to be common children’s fare at this time of year, but there’s nothing ordinary about this version. Given its premiere seven years ago as part of the Guggenheim Museum’s Works & Process series, this production combines performing arts with sets by renowned artists. Once again, Isaac Mizrahi, the story’s narrator, has designed the set and costumes and directed the tale, which has become a full theatrical production, with a cast of actors and choreography by John Heginbotham.
results.price: $35; $30 for members. Some shows are sold out, and seats are limited

results.web_description: Most of the time the Hannah Senesh Community Day School is devoted to education, but this Sunday it will be all about art (also a learning experience). Its classrooms will offer more than 10 workshops for both preschoolers and older children, many of them focusing on Hanukkah: making wire sculptures, edible dreidels, holiday cards, menorah wax catchers and Hanukkah headbands. Artists will lead the activities.

results.event_name: ‘A Christmas Carol, Oy! Hanukkah, Merry Kwanzaa’
results.web_description: No one could accuse Vit Horejs of being noninclusive or unecumenical, not with a show with this title. The founder of the Czechoslovak-American Marionette Theater, he has used Dickens’s tale as his framework, incorporating more than 30 puppets, two singers and a lot of multicultural references. Along with Scrooge, the show, which closes this weekend, features Hanukkah songs and caroling in Swahili.
results.cross_street: between Second Avenue and the Bowery
results.date_time_description: Dec. 5-14. Friday at 10 p.m.; Saturday at 2 and 10 p.m.; Sunday at 6 p.m.

results.web_description: This gentle musical set in Dublin, about a love affair that never quite happens  — ﻿ based on the 2006 movie  — ﻿ inventively uses songs (by Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova) and dance to convey a beautiful shimmer of might-have-been regret (2:15).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.event_name: Brooklyn Museum: ‘Connecting Cultures: A World in Brooklyn’
results.web_description: This eclectic, imaginatively thought-out one-gallery immersion experience in world art, all from Brooklyn’s collection and installed in the museum’s revamped Great Hall, serves as a teaser to the fabulous collections in the galleries beyond.

This journey involves not just miles, but years. In this permanent interactive exhibition at the Jewish Children’s Museum, young visitors can travel from Abraham and Sarah’s tent to the Western Wall in contemporary Jerusalem and beyond. Activities along the way include giving water to Rebecca’s camels, playing the strings on David’s harp (a high-tech version with beams of light that emit sounds when struck) and taking part in the exodus from Egypt. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; until 5:30 p.m. on Sundays. This Sunday, at 12:30 and 2 p.m., the museum is offering a workshop, “Soil to Oil,” that involves pressing olives and making oil for a Hanukkah menorah. And from Wednesday through Dec. 24, the museum holds its Hanukkah Art Festival, with craft workshops, a menorah mural, olive pressing and more.
results.price: regular museum admission: $13; $10 for 65+; free for under 2.
results.date_time_description: Usual hours: daily, except Fridays and Saturdays, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; until 5:30 p.m. on Sundays.

results.web_description: This free tour meets at 11 a.m. on the southwest corner of Madison Square Park, at 23rd Street and Broadway, in front of the William Seward statue. Sponsored by the Flatiron/23rd Street Partnership.

(in previews; opens on Dec. 14) This musical odyssey — returning to the stage after a short run on Broadway last year — examines the life of “The Singing Rabbi,” Shlomo Carlebach, a key figure in popular Jewish music, and his friendship with Nina Simone. The show is directed by Mindy Cooper, with a book by Daniel S. Wise and lyrics by David Schechter.

Here’s a learning experience for which you never have to sit still. In this new program at the Audubon Center in Prospect Park, a naturalist will lead children to places where they can play games that relate to the local flora and fauna, whether it’s animal charades or imitating a bat chasing a moth. Sundays also offer a Discover Tour in which families take a walk to look for animals and observe their habitats.
results.street_address: near the Lincoln Road and Ocean Avenue entrance of the park
results.date_time_description: "Nature on the Go" is Sundays from 1 to 2 p.m.; Discover Tours are Sundays at 3 p.m.

results.web_description: Inspired by Lewis Carroll’s “Alice” books, this transporting immersive theater work occupies a dreamscape where the judgments and classifications of the waking mind are suspended. A guided tour of Wonderland, created by Third Rail Projects, leads its participants through a series of rooms and an interactive evening of dance, poetry, food and drink (2:00).
results.venue_name: The Kingsland Ward at St. John's
results.cross_street: between Graham Avenue and Humboldt Street

results.web_description: The lights of Hanukkah, which begins at sundown on Tuesday,  should gleam a little more vividly at the homes of families who take part in this holiday workshop. Participants will first tour the collection of menorahs at the Yeshiva University Museum and hunt for miniature menorahs in its show “Modeling the Synagogue: From Dura to Touro,” which features scale models of synagogues worldwide. Children will then create mock stained-glass panels to place in windows next to their menorahs at home.
results.cross_street: between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas
results.price: free with museum admission: $8; $6 for students and 62+; free for members, children under 5, and faculty, administrators and students of Yeshiva University. Reservations are required.

results.web_description: Jacob Marley instigates the critical visitations in “A Christmas Carol,” but he’s hardly a star. That’s not true in this Dickens adaptation by Israel Horovitz, in which Marley does much more than threaten and rattle his chains: he’s the narrator and a major player. The Theater at Trinity is doing its annual staged reading of the work, in which the audience gets involved too.

results.event_name: Menorah Lighting in Grand Army Plaza
results.web_description: The huge menorah at Grand Army Plaza, at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, will be lit at 5:30 p.m. on the first night of Hanukkah. Sponsored by the Lubavitch Youth Organization, the nightly lightings will continue through Dec. 23, with most taking place at 5:30 p.m. (except on Fridays, when they are at 3:40 p.m., and Saturdays, at 8:30 p.m.). On Dec. 21, festivities will include music, dancing and latkes (potato pancakes).

This ultimate and most enduring of makeover stories, via the team who gave us “Oklahoma!,” has been restyled by the director Mark Brokaw and the writer Douglas Carter Beane into a glittery patchwork of snark and sincerity, with a whole lot of fancy ball gowns (2:20).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 3 (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with an added show on Dec. 29)

results.web_description: Cyndi Lauper has created a love-and-heat-seeking score that performs like a pop star on Ecstasy. This Harvey Fierstein-scripted tale of lost souls in the shoe business, in which a young factory owner teams up with a drag queen (Billy Porter), sometimes turns into a sermon. But it’s hard to resist the audience-hugging charisma of the songs (2:20).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: The most satisfying and subversive musical ever to come out of Britain. Directed by Matthew Warchus, with a book by Dennis Kelly and addictive songs by Tim Minchin, this adaptation of Roald Dahl’s novel is an exhilarating tale of empowerment, told from the perspective of that most powerless group, little children (2:35).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving and Christmas Eve, with an added show on Nov. 24)

results.web_description: A dramatically slapdash but musically vibrant joy ride through the glory days of the Detroit music label founded by Berry Gordy. Mr. Gordy’s book is sketchy and obvious — you want to plug your ears whenever the music stops. But the music is, of course, some of the greatest R&B ever recorded, and the performers mostly electric (2:40).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 18 (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Diane Paulus sends in the acrobats for her exhaustingly energetic revival of Stephen Schwartz and Roger O. Hirson’s 1972 musical. As for the 99-pound story at the center of this muscle-bound spectacle — the one about the starry-eyed son of Charlemagne — that’s there too, if you look hard (2:35).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performances on Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: This invigorating poperetta, conceived by David Byrne, sets a new standard for audience participation. Or do I mean coercion? In this heady show about the heady life of Imelda Marcos, staged with infinite inventiveness by Alex Timbers, all the world’s a dance floor, and all the men and women (including the audience) merely disco rats (1:30).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 3 (no performance on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and New Year's Day)

results.web_description: Each month the Audubon Center in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, sets up shop in a different area of the park to investigate a particular ecosystem or type of wildlife. May’s theme is “Wonderful Warblers,” which includes, at 2 p.m., “Nature on the Go,” a program in which families will learn how to identify these birds and make their own binoculars to view them. In “Nature’s Helpers,” at 3, children will help clean the park while exploring it, and in “Family Bird-Watching,” at 4, they’ll walk along the Lullwater Trail and try to spot some winged migrants. On Saturdays only, families can also take part in an introduction to bird-watching at the Audubon Center at noon.
results.street_address: the Willink entrance, Flatbush Avenue and Empire Boulevard, or the Lincoln Road and Ocean Avenue entrance
results.date_time_description: Saturdays and Sundays from 2 to 5 p.m.

results.web_description: (Monday) entertainment of its kind. (It opened in 1997.) Every Monday a different group of magicians appears (or disappears, as the case may be), offering illusions, sleight of hand and an occasional thrill, like knife throwing. The performers planned for this Monday are Torkova, the Great Throwdini and Peter Samelson.
results.price: $66.50 to $72.50; $10 discounts available on  phone orders with the codes HPG-Prem or HPG-VIP

results.web_description: At this hourlong Off Broadway production, it isn’t the names that go up in lights. Founded by Miral Kotb, a dancer and software engineer, the troupe  iLuminate uses wireless programs to light up the bodies of its performers, turning them into glowing silhouettes that perform in total darkness. Using music, dance and virtually no dialogue, the company tells the story of Jacob, an artist whose magic paintbrush, which turns his creations into living beings, is stolen for evil ends. The results tend to favor technology over art, but it’s still fun to watch these young dancers shine.
results.price: $49.99 and $69.99; $26 for rush and student tickets, available at the box office only
results.date_time_description: Fridays and Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 2:30 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 and 7 p.m.; Mondays and Wednesdays at 7 p.m.

results.web_description: Attending this bawdy, ridiculous, unauthorized parody of the harebrained sitcom “Saved by the Bell” is a bit like going to a midnight screening of “The Rocky Horror Picture Show,” given the many inside jokes and synchronized audience responses. Audience members know the material so well because half the humor comes from merely reproducing every ludicrous plot twist and trope from the TV show (including Zack’s giant cellphone, Becky the Duck and other allusions that will be familiar to longtime fans). The other half of the humor is just good old-fashioned raunch, usually playing up the horrifying ways to reinterpret a squeaky-clean children’s show (2:00).

Playing eight different victims of a sweet-faced killer (Bryce Pinkham) in Edwardian England, Jefferson Mays sings, dances, prances and generally makes infectious merriment in this daffy, ingenious show, winner of the Tony Award for best musical. Written with real wit by Robert L. Freedman and Steven Lutvak, the show has been stylishly directed by Darko Tresnjak (2:20).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Christmas Day and New Year's Day, with added performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: This friendly, formulaic jukebox show about the New York-born singer-songwriter might as well be called “Brooklyn Girl,” so closely does it adhere to the template of the megahit “Jersey Boys” (about the Four Seasons). Jessie Mueller, though, is extraordinary as Ms. King, making us feel the connection between a singer and her songs (2:25).
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: How do you describe a show whose script changes with every performance? A few reliable statements: Smooching, sword fighting and water spraying will occur. “Aaarr!” will be heard often. And, most important, it will provide more laughs than there are bones in Davy Jones’s locker. So it goes in this hour long family musical, created by Christopher Leidenfrost, in which a pirate crew is cursed by a sea witch and has to perform a Broadway-style spectacle to get its treasure. Young audience members help write the scenes, in the style of the game Mad Libs. (The run is open-ended.)
results.price: $39 to $99; the $39 tickets are available only by calling or visiting the box office

results.web_description: Children will be working on the railroad, not all the livelong day but for a few hours, in this program at the DiMenna Children’s History Museum of the New-York Historical Society. But the work will be fun: From 1 to 3 p.m., visitors ages 3 to 6 are invited to decorate a car for the Transcontinental Railroad, drawing inspiration from all the toy trains on display in the museum’s exhibition “Holiday Express: Toys and Trains From the Jerni Collection.” They can also go on a scavenger hunt through the collection and meet the friendly Conductor Abe, who will relate railroad stories.
results.price: free with museum admission:  $19; $15 for 65+; $12 for students; $6 for ages 5 through 13; free for under 5 and members

results.web_description: The class clown gets applause, not detention, at this series, in which tween and teenage comics perform stand-up. At this show, the young comedians will consider all that’s laughable about the holidays, whether it’s that horrible sweater from Grandma or the carolers who won’t stay on key. The material is recommended for children 9 and older, but there’s no need to worry about appropriateness (profanity is banned) or knock-knock jokes (this crew is sophisticated).
results.price: $15, with a one-item (soda or food) minimum. Reservations required.

results.web_description: The latest and most lavish of this city’s immersive theater experiments includes cocktails, a meal and a circus-style floor show, in addition to any number of possible intimate, eroticism-tinged (but PG-13) encounters with the comely young cast members. The show is not for those prone to social anxiety, but it’s full of gaudy spectacle, with a fin-de-Bloomberg-era vibe (2:45).
results.venue_name: Diamond Horseshoe at the Paramount Hotel

results.event_name: New York Society Library: ‘From the Western Front and Beyond: The Writings of World War I’
results.web_description: Written accounts of the war, including letters from soldiers, are included in this display commemorating the centenary of World War I. Drawn from this library’s collection, the exhibition includes pieces by writers like Arthur Conan Doyle, George Bernard Shaw, Rudyard Kipling and H.G. Wells as well as writings by ambulance drivers and clergy members. There are also works by the Scottish etcher Muirhead Bone.
results.date_time_description: through Dec. 31. Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., Tuesdays and Thursdays from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m., Sundays from 1 to 5 p.m.

results.event_name: ‘Sex Tips for Straight Women From a Gay Man’
results.web_description: Matt Murphy’s one-act is a blend of a bachelorette party at Chippendales and the embarrassing midnight show at some tourist trap in Pigalle. Talented cast, but it’s no “Queer Eye”  (1:20).

When it comes to potential for satire, E.L. James’s she-porn best seller, “50 Shades of Grey,” seems as easy a target as you could shake a sex toy at. That said, this exuberant takeoff handily delivers the goods, barreling along with a score steeped in show tunes, R&B, gospel, Gilbert and Sullivan and lyrics packed with references to various practices and orifices. “This is real life; this isn’t a book,” says Ana, the show’s heroine, to her tycoon suitor. “If it was, it would be terrible.” It certainly would. But “50 Shades!” is a musical parody, and a very entertaining one (1:30).

Casey Nicholaw (“The Book of Mormon”) directs and choreographs (and choreographs, and choreographs) the latest Disney musical, adapted from the 1992 animated movie. While the familiar formulas are not entirely abandoned, Mr. Nicholaw and the book writer, Chad Beguelin, stuff so much splashy, shticky business into this show that the more syrupy bits hardly register. James Monroe Iglehart stands out as the showboating, scene-stealing genie (2:20).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day, with added shows on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.event_name: Metropolitan Museum of Art: ‘Making Pottery Art: The Robert A. Ellison Jr. Collection of French Ceramics (ca. 1880-1910)’
results.web_description: Nearly all the 40 works in this show — from a collection recently donated to the museum — are in a traditional form of vases, bowls and platters. They represent a marvelous variety of styles and influences, including Art Nouveau, Arts and Crafts, classic Chinese traditions, and European folk art. What they share is a love for processes and materials and a candid way with the human touch. Most intriguing of all is a curiously clunky small vase by Paul Gauguin, who might have been the George Ohr of European ceramics if he’d stuck with it.

results.event_name: ‘Into the Third Dimension: 3-D Printing for Young Artists’
results.web_description: Imagine that a robot or a fairy or a lion came out of a child’s drawing and acquired three dimensions. It sounds like an animated fantasy, but the Children’s Museum of the Arts is making something very similar happen in this new exhibition. A collaboration with 3DP4E (3-D Printing for Everyone), this show features works from the museum’s permanent collection of children’s art. Each drawing is shown alongside one of its elements or details that’s been made three-dimensional through the printing process. On selected Saturdays — the next date is Dec. 13 — the museum will hold drawing workshops in which children can create art to enter into a raffle to be selected for 3-D printing.
results.price: free with museum admission: $11; free for 65+,  under 1 and members
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 11. Fridays and Thursdays from noon to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Mondays and Wednesdays from noon to 5 p.m.

results.web_description: More spectacle than story, “iLuminate” offers technology as its most dazzling star. Conceived, produced and directed by Miral Kotb, a former software engineer, the show employs about a dozen talented, indefatigable young actor-dancers, encased in black suits wired with digitally controlled lights. Performing in total darkness to a score combining hip-hop, jazz and classical influences, they portray the tale of an artist whose magic paintbrush is stolen for evil ends. Much of  the action is like a neon comic book, but it does have its magic moments (:55).

This new musical from Tom Kitt and Brian Yorkey (“Next to Normal”) is a gleaming drawing board of a show, full of polished surfaces and clearly drawn lines. The shiny-voiced Idina Menzel portrays a conflicted urban planner pondering two different roads her life might have taken. The show feels less like a variation on a theme, than a dogged reiteration of it (2:35).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: It’s back — again. Capitalizing on the popular movie, Claude-Michel Schönberg and Alain Boublil’s musical about the French fellow who steals a loaf of bread and lives to regret it storms Broadway in a new production. Ramin Karimloo, as the long-suffering bread-stealer, and Will Swenson, as his relentless foe, give a sterling performances (2:50).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Vital Theater Company has again revived this show, which takes place on one of the most treacherous, complicated and unrelenting battlefields to which America has sent its young: middle school. An attempt to attract audiences as old as 12, it draws on the first novel in a series by Sheryl Berk and her young daughter, Carrie Berk. Though not always plausible, the production, written by Rick Hip-Flores, offers a brisk, entertaining and well-acted hour as it explores what happens to the misfit heroine, Kylie Carson, when she starts a cupcake club that threatens to become even more popular than the reigning mean girl at school.
results.date_time_description: Oct. 4-Jan. 25. Fridays at 7 p.m.; Sundays at 4 p.m.; only on Sundays after Dec. 14

results.web_description: Only a decade after it closed, Sam Mendes and Rob Marshall’s popular, audience-teasing reincarnation of this classic musical feels as if it never left us. Alan Cumming seems to be having the time of his life reprising the creepy, tragic M.C., a role he redefined for the ages. In her Broadway debut, Emma Stone is scintillating as an attention-addicted Sally Bowles (2:30).
results.date_time_description: through March 29 (no performances on Christmas and New Year's Day, with added shows on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: (PG, 1:20, in either French or English) A tale of mice and bears, derring-do and dentistry, this lovely animated movie about would-be foes who become friends originated in a cycle of children’s books by the Belgian writer and artist Gabrielle Vincent. The books have simple stories and enchanting illustrations by Vincent that are characterized by graceful lines, muted colors and blurred edges, which focuses your attention on animals that, in their poignant delicacy, evoke Beatrix Potter. The screen character designs are broader and more overtly comic, but the three directors — Benjamin Renner, Vincent Patar and Stéphane Aubier — have retained enough of Vincent’s charming vision that the movie feels intimate and personal, as if it, too, had sprung from a single hand.

results.event_name: Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum: ‘Masters of Disguise: The World of Camouflage’
results.web_description: The art of camouflage in nature and its appropriation by hunters and the armed forces are explored in this exhibition, which uses digital images, artifacts and interactive elements to showcase how color, shade and shapes can be used to deceive the eye.
results.price: $24; $20 for students and 62+; $19 for ages 7 to 17; $12 for ages 3 to 6; free for under 3, active or retired military members, and museum members
results.date_time_description: through Feb. 24. Daily, from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.;  closed on Christmas Day

results.web_description: Michael C. Hall plays an “internationally ignored song stylist” of uncertain gender in John Cameron Mitchell and Stephen Trask’s 1998 rock musical about love and loss. Michael Mayer directed this mightily entertaining exercise in crowd control (1:30).
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, New Year's Eve and New Year's Day, with performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.event_name: American Museum of Natural History: ‘Pterosaurs: Flight in the Age of Dinosaurs’
results.web_description: The earliest known vertebrates to fly, pterosaurs large and small roamed the skies more than 60 million years ago. This exhibition examines the lives of these creatures with fossils, casts and life-size models as well as videos and interactive simulations.
results.price: Included in Museum Plus One admission (general admission and one Imax film or special exhibition): $27; $22 for students and 60+; $16 for ages 2 to 12. Member tickets: $13.50; $8.50 for children.
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; closed Christmas Day

results.web_description: (PG-13, 2:16) Given how little creative wiggle room there is in properties like “The Winter Soldier,” a sequel to “Captain America: The First Avenger” (2011), it counts as a minor triumph that the directors, the brothers Anthony and Joe Russo, imprint any personality on this new movie, which is less a stand-alone work than a part of an ever-expanding multimedia enterprise. As the World War II veteran turned contemporary superhero, Chris Evans remains a recessive if appealing screen presence.

(PG-13, 1:49) This promotional film for the N.F.L. is nothing special, but it is redeemed somewhat by Ivan Reitman’s smooth direction and the leathery professionalism of Kevin Costner as a Cleveland Brown’s general manager facing many tough decisions.

(No rating, 1:58, in Nepali and English) Stephanie Spray and Pacho Velez’s transporting ethnographic film, set in a green sliver of Nepal, consists of 11 uncut shots, most taken in a closed cable car. It’s a fascinating trip filled with men, women, children and the occasional animal who make for as gripping viewing as the landscape unfolding behind them. For 10 or so minutes at a time, each floats hundreds of feet above a lush forest, traveling to and from the Hindu temple that gives this film its rhythmic title. By focusing on such a narrow slice of life, Ms. Spray and Mr. Velez have ceded any totalizing claim on the truth and instead settled for a perfect incompleteness. Essential viewing.

(PG-13, 1:33, in Spanish and German) Set in Patagonia in the 1960s, this quietly jittery art house thriller hinges on a relationship that a young girl, Lilith (Florencia Bado), forms with a stranger (Alex Brendemühl, suave and icy) who turns out to be Josef Mengele. The Argentine writer and director Lucía Puenzo, shooting in wide screen, takes an effective, largely cool approach to her fictionalization of Mengele’s time in South America. She overworks some of her more blatant visual motifs, but the blond children at a local German school unsettle the mood nicely.

(No rating, 1:35) François Ozon’s coming-of-age story, in which an upper-middle-class French high school student (Marine Vacth) takes up prostitution as an extracurricular activity, is coy and prurient rather than illuminating, and oddly dull even when it tries to be provocative.

(No rating, 1:25) A kind of forensic memorial, Marc Silver’s documentary pieces together the background of a Central American migrant worker who died trying to cross into the United States. With its multifaceted approach, its earnest compassion and a celebrity presence in the form of the actor Gael García Bernal, the movie could be enlisted in the perennial battle over immigration law, but its execution presents problems not containable by the filmmakers’ noble intention.

(R, 1:30) John Turturro directed, and stars in, this low-key, low-energy comedy as a former bookstore employee turned prostitute whose pimp is played by none other than a deftly funny Woody Allen. It’s a story of New York haves and have-nots that never manages to persuade, despite the engaging supporting likes of Sharon Stone, Sofía Vergara, Vanessa Paradis and especially Liev Schreiber as a hunky Hasidic neighborhood cop.

(No rating, 1:30, in English, French, German and Spanish) Cheerfully partial and unapologetically deferential, Frank Pavich’s account of the Chilean director Alejandro Jodorowsky’s failed efforts to film Frank Herbert’s science fiction novel “Dune” bristles with offbeat talent, revelatory art work and operatic self-promotion.

(R, 1:25) Steven Knight’s movie about a man in lockdown — emotionally, psychologically, existentially —  asks you to spend 85 minutes in intimate quarters with Tom Hardy, who’s mostly seen in medium close-up behind a steering wheel. It’s a story about a man on the verge of making a life-changing decision and, like a lot of road movies, the journey is the destination. Moment by moment, with a twitch, a shudder, a look, Mr. Hardy movingly draws you in, turning a stranger’s face into a life.

(PG-13, 1:49) Cameron Diaz has her hands full with this female revenge comedy, a shrill, lazy, clumsily assembled rip-off of “The First Wives Club” that could crush any actor forced to execute its leaden slapstick gags and mouth its crude humorless dialogue.

(PG-13, 1:38) In this latest horror movie about weird doings in the 1970s, Jared Harris stars as an Oxford University professor who believes the supernatural occurrences in a patient’s bleak, lonely life have been created by her mind and is using every bad idea he has — including curing her through sleep deprivation — to prove it. As in other horror tales with doctors and scientists, the darkness emerges during the struggle between an ostensibly rational mind and the creatures that are manifestations of irrationality and, by their very existence, emblems of religious faith. Too bad it isn’t scary.

(PG-13, 1:30) This Detroit-set remake of the French action movie “District B13” is fast and loud, as it should be — with plenty of car chases and parkour — but it also has a tantalizing hint of class consciousness and a dollop of streetwise wit, mostly thanks to RZA of the Wu-Tang Clan, who plays a drug kingpin with unusual priorities.

Young visitors may want to put on their dancing shoes before they visit this show at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan. Then again, on certain days they can just wait and make a pair there. Presented in conjunction with the National Jazz Museum in Harlem, this exhibition revisits the Harlem Renaissance with displays dedicated to major jazz figures, highlighting Ella Fitzgerald, Bill (Bojangles) Robinson and Duke Ellington. Activities include song, dance, investigations of musical composition and craft workshops that include, yes, building your own tap shoes. Performances will be a regular part of the show.
results.price: free with admission: $11; $7 for 65+; free for members and under 1; free to all from 5 to 8 p.m. on the first Friday of every month
results.date_time_description: May 23-Dec. 31. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., except Mondays (open on holiday Mondays); until 7 p.m. on Saturdays; open until 8 p.m. the first Friday of every month.

results.event_name: New York Hall of Science: Rocket Park Mini Golf
results.web_description: While circumventing NASA rockets (no longer in use, don’t worry), guests can tee off at this outdoor course, which imitates the path of a complete spaceflight. Players must be precise to avoid gravity wells, wormholes and asteroids, and will learn about spacecrafts and the laws of motion along the way.
results.venue_name: New York Hall of Science, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park
results.price: $17, $13 for 18 and under, students and 62+, which includes museum admission

results.web_description: Yes, it’s great to study the piano or the flute or the trumpet. But imagine being able to say that you play the theremin. That’s really cool — or at least that’s what the New York Theremin Society will try to persuade young people in this theremin workshop for kids. This crash course, taught by Dorit Chrysler and Rob Schwimmer, will teach how to play the instrument, but even if participants don’t emerge as experts, they’ll refine their motor skills and train their ears.
results.price: $35; free for accompanying adults. (Space is limited, and registration is required.)
results.date_time_description: Dec. 13 at 11 a.m. (ages 4 through 6) and 12:30 p.m. (ages 7 and older)

results.web_description: Joe Assadourian, who served 12 years in prison for attempted murder, wrote and stars in this very funny one-man show about the characters he met while awaiting his trial (1:05).
results.cross_street: between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas

results.event_name: Museum of Sex: ‘Funland: Pleasures and Perils of the Erotic Fairground’
results.web_description: This exhibition, organized by the Conceptual artists Sam Bompas and Harry Parr, explores the eroticism of carnivals and fairs through films and interactive displays. In his review for The New York Times, Edward Rothstein wrote, “though it encloses just 2,000 square feet, with five ‘attractions,’ there is no body part commonly thought private that is not here publicly grasped, modeled or bounced against, with a mixture of vulgarity, playfulness, inventiveness, crudity, childishness and mischievous provocation.” That said, this show is for those 18 and older.
results.date_time_description: daily from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m., until 9 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays; closed Christmas Day

results.web_description: Seeing this new Imax film at the American Museum of Natural History may inspire fear — not for the safety of humans, but for that of sharks. Shown in both 2-D and 3-D, this documentary explores the fate of great white sharks, which have been driven to the brink of extinction by the market for shark fin soup. Filmed in waters off Mexico, New Zealand, South Africa and the California coast, the work captures sharks in their habitats, including a sequence in which great whites are shown breaching in 3-D.
results.price: included in Museum Plus One admission (general admission and one Imax  film or special exhibition): $27; $22 for students and 60+; $16 for ages 2 to 12; $13.50 for members; $8.50 for children of members
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4. Hourly, seven days a week, from 10:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., with 2-D screenings at 11:30 a.m. and 4:30 p.m.; all other showings are 3-D; closed Christmas Day

results.web_description: Stops on this tour, led by Wall Street Walks, include the New York Stock Exchange, Trinity Church, the Wall Street Bull, and ground zero and the Sept. 11 memorial. Tours cost $27, last 90 minutes and begin at 11 a.m. and 1:30 p.m. (Also at 3 p.m. on Tuesdays and Fridays.)
results.date_time_description: Weekdays at 11 a.m. and 1:30 p.m. (also at 3 p.m. on Tuesdays and Fridays)

results.event_name: Bronx Museum of the Arts: ‘Beyond the Supersquare’
results.web_description: In the mid-20th century, certain Latin American cities looked like the most modern cities on earth. Not only was their architecture imaginative, so were the ideas behind it: that design could shape civic life; that art and architecture were inseparable; that while Europe and the United States were the cultural powers of the day, South America had a shot at tomorrow. The momentum broke down when a rash of right-wing military coups swept the continent. But the link between art and architecture remained firm and continues to. That’s the subject of this subtle, buoyant think-piece of a show of contemporary work, which extends to an open-air pavilion, designed by Terence Gower, set in the lush garden of the Andrew Freedman home across from the museum.

results.event_name: ‘What’s Up, Doc? The Animation Art of Chuck Jones’
results.web_description: A whole lot of great cartoons, that’s what’s up. Chuck Jones (1912-2002), for many years one of the creative geniuses at Warner Bros., helped give life and indelible personalities to sassy characters like Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Wile E. Coyote, the Road Runner and many more. This new exhibition at the Museum of the Moving Image salutes his artistry with sketches, story boards, animation cels and photographs. Every Saturday and Sunday during the show’s run, the museum will present programs of Chuck Jones screenings. This three-day weekend (Saturday, Sunday and Monday), the museum will present  “‘Baton Bunny’ and Other Cartoons,” that bunny, of course, being Bugs.
results.price: free with admission: $12; $9 for 65+ and students; $6 for 3 to 12; free for under 3 and members;  free to all on Fridays from 4 to 8 p.m. and free to all on Sept. 21, while the museum is presenting the New York on Location festival. Screenings are first come first served, though members can reserve seats by phone
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 19. Hours: Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7 p.m.; (till 5 p.m. on Saturday, Oct. 11); Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Also open on Columbus Day from 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.

results.event_name: Morbid Anatomy Museum: ‘The Art of Mourning’
results.web_description: This exhibition contains items associated with mourning practices from the 18th to 20th centuries, including photographs, shadowboxes and memorial cards.
results.price: $8, $6 for students and 65+, free for children 12 and younger
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 5; daily (except Tuesdays) from noon to 6 p.m.

results.web_description: As brought to thin-skinned, full-blooded life by Michael Cera, Kieran Culkin and Tavi Gevinson, the three young characters in Anna D. Shapiro’s kinetically charged revival of this fine Kenneth Lonergan play are in a state of permanent free-fall. They exquisitely capture the sense of being lost, formless and on your own that descends with the end of adolescence (2:20).
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day, with added shows on Nov. 26, Dec. 24 and 31)

results.web_description: Shortening the word archaeology, this exhibition focuses on technology and obsolescence. Marianne Vitale’s sculptures made from steel components of railroad switches known as frogs are one highlight; Jessica Jackson Hutchins’s neo-hippie assemblages with found ceramics and a hand-woven hammock another. Across the bar from the Standard Hotel, Josh Kline takes the most activist stance, with smoothies made from prescription drugs and consumer products, while a mural by the veteran artist Ed Ruscha — a new commission separate from “Archeo” — announces “Honey, I Twisted Through More Damn Traffic Today,” perhaps capturing the ethos of the tourist-clogged High Line.
results.street_address: enter at Washington and Gansevoort Streets

results.event_name: Museum of Modern Art: ‘The Paris of Toulouse-Lautrec: Prints and Posters’
results.web_description: In his printed works, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec chronicled and publicized the music halls, theaters, circuses, operas and cafes of Paris with terrific verve, sly wit and surprising subtlety. This enthralling show presents approximately 100 examples drawn from the museum’s permanent collection.
results.cross_street: between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas

results.web_description: Names drop like hailstones in this revised revival of Terrence McNally’s comedy about the anxious opening night of a Broadway turkey. Celebrity performers (including Nathan Lane, Matthew Broderick and Stockard Channing) sling a lot of mud at other celebrities, sometimes hilariously. Jack O’Brien directs with gusto this fizzy, overlong work that eventually goes flat. Mr. Lane is sterling (2:30).
results.date_time_description: After closing at the Schoenfeld Theater on Jan. 18, "It's Only a Play" transfers to the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater on Jan. 23. (No performances on Christmas Day or New Year's Day, with added shows on Dec. 22 and 29.)

results.web_description: Kim Davies’s play about two young New Yorkers in a kitchen at a sex party is intense, provocative and exceedingly clever, with two exceptional performances by Stephen Stout and Madeleine Bundy. A study of power, it argues that sex is exactly like every other kind of human interaction, except maybe funnier (1:15).

A lot of shows make you laugh. But Scott Ellis’s felicitous revival of Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman’s 1936 comedy about an improbably happy family has you beaming from curtain to curtain. The delicious assorted nuts onstage include James Earl Jones, Rose Byrne, Kristine Nielsen and the sly comic genius Annaleigh Ashford (2:20).
results.date_time_description: through Feb. 22  (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Marcos Antonio Rodríguez stars in his own sociopolitical drama with ghosts. The plot points don’t all cohere, but this Repertorio Español production offers naughty-word humor and textured personal dynamics (1:45).
results.venue_name: Repertorio Espanol at Gramercy Arts Theater

results.event_name: ‘The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time’
results.web_description: Simon Stephens’s adaptation of Mark Haddon’s best-selling novel, about an autistic boy’s coming-of-age, is one of the most fully immersive works ever to wallop Broadway. Be prepared to have all your emotional and sensory buttons pushed. Marianne Elliott (“War Horse”) directs the excellent cast, led by Alex Sharp, and the dazzling technical team (2:25).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Today’s children may not know who Cary Grant and Katharine Hepburn are, but they’re sure to be intrigued by this 1938 film’s other star: the title character, a pet leopard. Directed by Howard Hawks, this comedy, in which the humans pursue the big cat, is part of the series Film Forum Jr., which introduces young audiences to classic cinema.
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue South

results.web_description: A.R. Gurney’s quietly moving epistolary play made its Broadway premiere with a sterling Brian Dennehy and an extraordinary Mia Farrow breathing vivid life into the lifelong correspondence between a man and a woman from the East Coast upper crust. The production now features Alan Alda and Candice Bergen. Gregory Mosher directs (1:30).

Hanky-panky-in-high-office scandals of recent years are transformed into comic burlesque in this clever comedy by Mario Correa. Drawing verbatim on the public record, the play, nimbly directed by Dan Knechtges, slices and dices the misbehavior of four politicians: Larry Craig (airport bathroom sting), Mark Foley (he of the underage page scandal), Mark Sanford (“hiking the Appalachian Trail”) and, of course, Anthony Weiner. The excellent cast includes Rachel Dratch, playing all the female roles (1:15).
results.venue_name: Lynn Redgrave Theater at Culture Project

results.event_name: Asia Society and Museum: Nam June Paik: ‘Becoming Robot’
results.web_description: Close on the heels of a large Nam June Paik survey in Washington last year comes this show, which seems to have two aims in mind: to situate Paik, who was born in Korea in 1932 but spent most of his career in New York, as a prescient imaginer of various forms of digital technology and social media; and to consider his identity as an Asian artist, or at least as a kind of Zen floater who made some of his most interesting work from pixels and sound waves circling through space.

results.event_name: Rubin Museum of Art: ‘Francesco Clemente: Inspired by India’
results.web_description: The first Clemente retrospective in New York in more than a decade ties the peripatetic Italian-born painter to a single country. At just 20 works or so, it’s not exactly comprehensive. It is, however, thoroughly immersive. The installation, in the Rubin’s skylit top-floor galleries, evokes the structure of an Indian temple with a combination of large and small spaces; it has an open central area of paintings, intimate nooks for sculpture and a “sanctum” of watercolors. This finely articulated sense of place is the most novel aspect of an exhibition that otherwise, like many previous Clemente exhibitions, seems to coast on his cosmopolitan charms.
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue

results.event_name: Metropolitan Museum of Art: Amie Siegel: ‘Provenance’
results.web_description: Stylish aesthetics and fashionable conceptualism trump documentary realism in “Provenance,” an extremely suave film by Amie Siegel. The 40-minute movie is an instance of institutional critique, an art genre that tries to expose and subvert the workings of the capitalist art market. Specifically, it’s about the scandalous trade in furniture produced for Chandigarh, the utopian city in northern India designed by Le Corbusier and his team and built between 1951 and 1965. Although visually and emotionally captivating, it leaves obscure details that a more conventional documentary would bring to light.

results.event_name: Museum of the Moving Image: ‘What’s Up, Doc? The Animation Art of Chuck Jones’
results.web_description: One of the great producers of animated cartoons in the predigital era, Mr. Jones created the Road Runner and Wile E. Coyote and made movies starring previously existing characters like Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck. This entertaining show includes 136 original drawings and paintings and has 23 video versions of films directed by Mr. Jones showing in whole or in parts in a screening room and on monitors throughout.

results.event_name: Jewish Museum: ‘From the Margins: Lee Krasner and Norman Lewis, 1945-1952’
results.web_description: Inspired by a pairing in the museum’s 2008 show “Action/Abstraction: Pollock, de Kooning and American Art, 1940-1976,” this exhibition orchestrates a profound and sensitive conversation between Krasner and Lewis — one that takes into account their shared visual language as well as different cultural backgrounds (as a Jewish woman and an African-American man). It also suggests that both artists have long been hidden in plain sight: Krasner as the spouse of an art celebrity, Lewis as a black artist whose paintings were more formal than political.

John Rando’s take on this merry mating dance of a musical from 1944, about sailors on shore leave, feels as fresh as first sunlight. With airborne choreography by Joshua Bergasse, the production presents a parallel-universe New York where hectic urban life acquires the grace of a storybook ballet. It’s a bustling, jostling cartoon that floats like a swan (2:35).
results.date_time_description: continuing  (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on  Dec. 22 and 29)

results.event_name: Brooklyn Museum: ‘Killer Heels: The Art of the High-Heeled Shoe’
results.web_description: Whether you view extra-high heels with lust or horror, as objects of empowerment or objectification, this in-depth survey of elevating footwear from past and present, East and West, is a model of the curatorial craft. It examines its subject from several fruitful angles, including unflattering ones, interspersed with excellent labels, relevant objects of art and especially design, clips from famous films and videos both didactic and artistic. Its main flaw: dim lighting dictated by fragile materials means that some shoes are most visible in the catalog.

results.event_name: ‘Somebody Come and Play: 45 Years of “Sesame Street” Helping Kids Grow Smarter, Stronger, and Kinder’
results.web_description: (Friday, Saturday, and Monday through Thursday) Sesame Street now has an additional address: the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. This new show showcases more than 250 artifacts related to the beloved preschool public television series “Sesame Street,” including set designs, original sketches for characters, scripts, storyboards, animation cels, Claymation models, videos and, of course, over 20 Muppets, among them Elmo, Zoe and Bert and Ernie. A children’s area includes “Sesame Street” books and activities.
results.venue_name: New York Public Library for the Performing Arts
results.date_time_description: Sept. 18-Jan. 31. Daily, except Sundays, from noon to 6 p.m.; to 8 p.m. on Mondays and Thursdays.

results.event_name: American Museum of Natural History: ‘Lonesome George’
results.web_description: His death in 2012 brought to an end the species of this Pinta Island tortoise of the Galápagos Islands, named Lonesome George for his largely singular existence. But thanks to naturalists here and in Ecuador and taxidermy specialists, he can be viewed as he appeared in life, with neck and limbs extended; following this exhibition, he will be returned to Ecuador.
results.price: suggested admission, $22; $17 for students and 60+; $12.50 for children 2 to 12
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; closed Christmas Day

results.web_description: This exhibition features more than 30 paintings and drawings of city bridges by the artist Anne Bascove, including the Brooklyn Bridge, the Outerbridge Crossing and the George Washington Bridge.
results.venue_name: Noble Maritime Collection, Snug Harbor Cultural Center and Botanical Garden
results.date_time_description: through July 12: Thursdays through Sundays from 1 to 5 p.m., and by appointment; closed on Christmas Day.

results.event_name: Metropolitan Museum of Art: ‘Assyria to Iberia at the Dawn of the Classical Age’
results.web_description: Is art from the past pertinent to present? Absolutely. The evidence is there in this magnificently complex show of art from parts of the Middle East, or as the Met prefers to call it, the Near East, that now include Iran, Iraq, Israel, Lebanon, Syria and Turkey. The exchange of materials, ideas and beliefs traced in shipwreck-salvaged objects here speak of a world as globally networked as our own. The wars depicted in Assyrian relief panels are as horrific as those being fought on the same turf today. Look at any precious thing in the show — a Babylonian gold pendant, a Phoenician ivory carving — and know that their equivalents are being looted and sent to destinations unknown today.

A shipbuilding town in decline is the setting for this earnest, ambitious musical with a wonderful score by Sting (who is now starring), and a somewhat diffuse book by John Logan (“Red”) and Brian Yorkey (“Next to Normal”). Fine performances  — notably Michael Esper as the wayward son and Rachel Tucker as the love he left behind — enliven the proceedings, as does the atmospheric production directed by Joe Mantello (2:25).
results.date_time_description: continuing  (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Ayad Akhtar’s tense, turbulent Pulitzer Prize-winner about the clash between Islamic faith and modern culture comes roaring onto Broadway with a superb, mostly new cast under Kimberly Senior’s taut direction. Hari Dhillon gives a coiled, stealthy performance as the Pakistani-born, well-heeled and thoroughly assimilated New Yorker whose assumptions about his identity are shaken when his complacent life comes unraveled. Gretchen Mol is excellent as his artist wife, and Josh Radnor (“How I Met Your Mother”), Karen Pittman and Danny Ashok give fine support (1:25).
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue
results.date_time_description: through Feb. 15  (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Authenticity is conspicuous only by its absence in Sam Gold’s revival of Tom Stoppard’s 1982 comedy about one all-too-witty writer’s emotional block. Despite a talented big-name cast led by Ewan McGregor and Maggie Gyllenhaal and the expected witty dialogue, evidence of real feelings, real chemistry and real life in general is dishearteningly scarce (2:15).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performances on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve, with added shows on Nov. 24, Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: These informal weekly gatherings feature film screenings, performances and discussions at the SoHo loft of the choreographer and video artist Cathy Weis. The fall season concludes with Ms. Weis performing her 2009 solo “The Bottom Fell Out of the Tub,” as well as excerpts from her “Haiku” series with the performer Ashley Brockington and the musician Lee Free.

results.event_name: Ragnar Kjartansson and the National: ‘A Lot of Sorrow’
results.web_description: The Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson and the indie rock band the National collaborate on this unusually enjoyable feat of endurance art: a six-hour video of the National performing its popular song “Sorrow” — for six hours. The power and nuance of music, the discipline and creativity of musicians, the joy of live performance are revealed and even intensified.

Sarah Ruhl’s new play explores the conflict between the nuclear family and Tibetan Buddhist tradition, when an American boy is identified as the reincarnation of a revered monk and teacher. Celia Keenan-Bolger portrays the conflicted mother in this tenderly drawn but tame and rather predictable play, directed by Rebecca Taichman (2:00).
results.venue_name: Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, Lincoln Center

results.web_description: In his review for The New York Times, Edward Rothstein called it a “vigorous and imaginative new exhibition,” that includes a look at “how Chinese-American identity came to be, how immigration and discrimination were followed by recrimination and conflict, and how, finally, a people’s trials give way to celebration.”
results.price: $19, $15 for 65+, educators or active military, $12 for students, $6 for 5- to 13-year-olds, free for 4 and younger
results.date_time_description: through April 19. Tuesdays through Thursdays and Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., Fridays till 8 p.m.; Sundays from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.

results.event_name: Museum of Modern Art: ‘Robert Gober: The Heart Is Not a Metaphor’
results.web_description: This 35-year retrospective, haunting 13 beautifully-installed galleries at the museum, presents tenderly handmade sculptures and installations more real than surreal that are as American as apple pie — with the sugar left out. Their familiar yet startlingly altered forms — including playpens, sinks and easy chairs — and truncated human limbs and bodies, have a sharpness that continually bring us up short, conjuring memories both private and shared, including the attacks of Sept. 11.
results.cross_street: between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas

results.event_name: Brooklyn Museum: ‘Crossing Brooklyn: Art From Bushwick, Bed-Stuy and Beyond’
results.web_description: Billed as a “major survey” of Brooklyn artists, this 35-person show favors artists who venture outside their studios to do various activities social and otherwise. Much is tepid and didactic, but some things are amusing. Nobutaka Aozaki makes portraits of people using a black marker to add their distinctive features to the yellow smiley face on plastic shopping bags. In a triptych of video self-portraits that she made in an airplane lavatory, Nina Katchadourian lip-syncs to a Bee Gees song. A video by William Lamson in which at certain points he appears to be standing on the calm surface of the Delaware River has a transcendentalist vibe.

Inspired by the cartoon art of Saul Steinberg and the movie “Who Framed Roger Rabbit?”, this 23-artist show invites viewers to consider the ways and wherefores of comical art. It’s generally more droll than laugh-out-loud funny. Consisting mostly of three-dimensional objects, it focuses on comedic art’s formal properties like absurdist contradiction, exaggerated scale and dysfunctional mechanics.

Though embodied by the stellar likes of Glenn Close and John Lithgow, the angsty suburbanites at the center of Pam MacKinnon’s revival of Edward Albee’s existential drawing-room drama have the flattened dimensions of specimens under glass. The cast (with the welcome exceptions of Clare Higgins and Bob Balaban) seems to be giving us the play instead of living it (2:45).

Apprehension permeates every atom of Scott Elliott’s fascinating revival of  David Rabe’s strange, angry, messy and deeply disturbing 1971 drama about a Vietnam veteran’s return to a suburban world that refuses to absorb him. A brilliant Bill Pullman and Holly Hunter are a sitcom perfect mom and dad who find their all-American denial under siege (2:45).

The indie film actor John Hawkes (“The Sessions,” “Winter’s Bone”) and Tracie Thoms give terrific performances in David Auburn’s two-hander about people facing similar crises. Mr. Auburn avoids the pitfall of predictability — no romance ensues — but he isn’t able to work up much dramatic heat in this muted drama (1:30).
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue

results.event_name: Metropolitan Museum of Art: ‘Thomas Hart Benton’s “America Today” Mural Rediscovered’
results.web_description: The prickly American Regionalist Thomas Hart Benton had his share of detractors. But even they would probably acknowledge that his early mural “America Today” is the best of its kind, a raucous, cartwheeling, wide-angle look at 1920s America that set the standard for the Works Progress Administration’s mural program and has remained a New York City treasure. Now installed at the Met in a reconstruction of its original setting (a boardroom at the New School for Social Research), it captivates with period details (from the cut of a flapper gown to the mechanics of a blast furnace) and timely signs of socioeconomic and environmental distress (exhausted coal miners and hands reaching for coffee and bread).

results.event_name: Museum of Arts and Design: ‘What Would Mrs. Webb Do? A Founder’s Vision’
results.web_description: Paying tribute to museum founder Aileen Osborn Webb (1892-1979), a well-connected philanthropist, patron of the arts and, in the museum’s new parlance, a “maker,” this collection show rich in mid-century objects also brings to life Mrs. Webb’s craft-related activities and organizations beyond the museum. (She had founded the American Craft Council in 1939 and, before that, organized cooperatives of craftspeople up the Hudson in Putnam County during the Depression.) With her vision of a museum connected to various networks and marketplaces, Mrs. Webb affirmed craft — or “making,” or whatever you call it — as a deeply social activity and a source of economic self-empowerment.

Of the approximately 125 items in this terrific show, there are only 11 oil paintings, which is a good thing. Except for a large picture of his wife, Edith, in a colorful striped dress, Schiele’s works on canvas are dark and turgid. But his drawings are nimble and nuanced. Working on paper with pencil, charcoal, ink, gouache, watercolor and crayons, he portrayed himself and others with infectious avidity. There’s hardly a single sheet here that doesn’t warrant close looking for its virtuoso draftsmanship and psychological acuity.

This 1997 musical by Bill Russell and Henry Krieger about the real-life conjoined twins Daisy and Violet Hilton, who became vaudeville stars in the 1930s, has received a thrilling revival. The rich score, and a newly revised book with contributions from the director, Bill Condon (best known for his film work), establish this adventurous musical as an indispensable ticket for the season. Erin Davie and Emily Padgett are luminous and affecting as the twins united by flesh but separated by their divergent ambitions (2:30).
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, with added performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Katori Hall’s transfixing drama, set in Rwanda in the early 1980s, explores what happens when three Catholic schoolgirls claim to see visions of the Virgin Mary. The superb cast, under the sensitive direction of Michael Greif, makes us luxuriate in the suspension of disbelief — at least until the girls’ visions turn dark, and the pleasure turns to terror (2:20).

In this two-man show, the Australian actor John R. Waters (accompanied by the pianist Stewart D’Arrietta) wisely doesn’t attempt a complete impersonation. There are no glasses or beard or mop top here, just an evocative approximation of the voice and a deeply felt reflection of the man. The show amply covers spirited rockers, but much of it explores the darker depths that so distinguished Lennon from the sunnier Paul McCartney. The darkest corners — Lennon’s early abusive romantic relationships and his heroin use — are avoided. (No “Cold Turkey” here.) But the Beatle fanatics sure to see this show won’t mind (1:30).

Simon Stephens’s tender, ferocious and frightening play about a group of British school students during exam season inspires wonder that anybody makes it to the end of adolescence. Directed by Trip Cullman, this piercing study of kids’ inhumanity to kids is enacted by a marvelous cast that dares to go places most grown-ups like to forget exist (1:45).

Gossip gallops in the Bedlam troupe’s enchantingly athletic take on the perils of courtship according to Jane Austen, adapted by Kate Hamill and directed by Eric Tucker. Transposing Austen into the jauntier key of Dickens, this production reminds us that few theater companies ride narrative momentum as resourcefully or enthusiastically as Bedlam does. It’s an unconditional delight (2:30).
results.date_time_description: running in repertory with "The Seagull" through Dec. 21

results.web_description: Inescapably playful and undeniably serious, Bernard Shaw’s 1905 play pits a Salvation Army crusader (Hannah Cabell) against her armorer father (Dan Daily). Though occasionally stagey, David Staller’s production presents its ideas lucidly while never stinting the emotions that underlie them. Mr. Staller might easily adopt the armorer’s motto: “Unashamed” (2:15).

The minimalist director John Doyle deploys his tried-and-true formula of doubling actors as musicians in this glowing production of a seldom-revived Rodgers and Hammerstein curiosity from 1947. Though the show (about a morally conflicted small-town doctor) remains an odd duck, it sings beautifully, while making us newly aware of both the harmonies and deliberate dissonance within Rodgers’s score (1:30).

The nations-conquering, mass-murdering title character of Christopher Marlowe’s 1587 behemoth is here embodied by a truly titanic John Douglas Thompson as a force of nature in the sense that typhoons and tidal waves are. Michael Boyd’s surprisingly enjoyable, fast-moving interpretation is packed with pageantry, stylized violence and a coruscating theatrical wit that lets us chuckle uneasily even as we recoil (3:00).
results.cross_street: between Lafayette Avenue and Fulton Street
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performances on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, New Year's Eve and New Year's Day, with added performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Keith Josef Adkins has written a resplendently foulmouthed melodrama about “trailer trash in its natural habitat.” As staged by Leah C. Gardiner, this tale of a dead dog, a corrupt town and a rebellious, lust-provoking hillbilly (Yvette Ganier) sags at moments. But its dialogue is often as flavorful as pulled-pork barbecue, marinated in a piquant secret sauce (2:00).

The greatest chanteuse who never sung a note returns to the New York stage after an absence of nearly 10 years. That this three-part work, the creation of Lypsinka’s alter-ego, John Epperson, brilliantly assesses the toll taken on women by their facades should surprise no one. The third installment (“Show Trash”) introduces the shy man behind the overpowering diva (running in repertory: “Lypsinka: The Boxed Set”: 1:15; “The Passion of the Crawford”: 1:15; “John Epperson: Show Trash”: 1:30).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 3 (no performances on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Eve and New Year's Day)

results.web_description: Playing a withholding man in a woodland cabin in Jez Butterworth’s cryptic tease of a play, Hugh Jackman squelches his natural urge to ingratiate and ascends to a new level as a stage actor. Comparable claims cannot be made for Mr. Butterworth’s willfully enigmatic drama, though it has been beautifully staged by Ian Rickson. Expect to leave hungry (1:25).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 25 (no performances on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day and New Year's Eve, with added performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.event_name: Metropolitan Museum of Art: ‘Grand Design: Pieter Coecke van Aelst and Renaissance Tapestry’
results.web_description: The Met presents its third spectacular show of European tapestries in a dozen years and its first to concentrate on a single artist, the polymath Pieter Coecke van Aelst. It may repeatedly make you gasp, whether at the size or realness of the images, their human dramas and sumptuous surfaces, or simply the immense open space that forms the exhibition’s spine.

results.event_name: Metropolitan Museum of Art: ‘Cubism: The Leonard A. Lauder Collection’
results.web_description: This no-strings-attached gift of 81 Cubist works more than lives up to expectations. Concentrating on the four horsemen of the Cubist apocalypse (Braque, Gris, Léger and Picasso), it outlines the style’s heady transformation of art while giving the museum a foundation in modernism commensurate with its holdings in other eras. It’s a stunning show and thrilling event.

One of the most experimental of all postwar European art tendencies finally receives a full-dress survey in an American museum, one that was built and opened during its first flowering. While the work’s pursuit of newness — moving parts, mirrored surfaces and glowing lights — wears thin, the seamless pairing of exhibition and architecture is perfect. Both seem alternately radical and quaint.

The once imperiled dance space at 280 Broadway, recently revived by Gina Gibney, continues its inaugural series, DoublePlus, in which well-known contemporary choreographers select two artists to share an evening. In this weekend’s installment, put together by Jon Kinzel, Anna Azrieli uses the ubiquitous ballet position arabesque penché as the starting point for a study in mediocrity in her new work, “Averaging,” while Stuart Shugg, a popular dancer around town, blends film and athleticism in his offering, “Dear Washing Machine, Long Night.” For the final week of this six-week series, Bebe Miller invites and mentors Maree ReMalia and Abby Zbikowski, two up-and-coming choreographic voices. Beginning on Wednesday, Ms. ReMalia, who takes the stage name merrygogo, examines our ability to hold contradictory thoughts simultaneously in “now is now,” while Ms. Zbikowski and her two dancers present “Destabilizer,” which merges hip-hop and punk sensibilities.
results.venue_name: Gibney Dance: Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center
