results.date_time_description: Wednesdays through Saturdays at 7:30 p.m.; through Dec. 20

results.web_description: Bradley Cooper distorts himself with self-obliterating grace in this sturdy revival of Bernard Pomerance’s instructive, carefully arranged drama about a freak of nature in Victorian England. But the most emotionally involving performance comes from Alessandro Nivola as a surgeon suffering a crises of faith. Scott Ellis directs a cast that also includes an eccentric Patricia Clarkson (1:55).
results.date_time_description: through Feb. 15 (no performances on Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve; additional performances on  Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: This fascinating new drama written and directed by Young Jean Lee, among the most versatile and talented playwrights working today, asks us to sympathize with the existential crisis of a white middle-aged man who has refused to conform to the codes of achievement and privilege expected of him. He’s glad to be unhappy — or at least he refuses to pathologize his lack of worldly success — but his family can’t abide the idea (1:30).

Sam Shepard sends a forensic scientist into the realm of classical mythology to investigate the mystery of Oedipus Rex (Stephen Rea). Nancy Meckler’s time-traveling production doesn’t dig up many new insights, but Mr. Shepard seems to be having a good time contemplating the nature of tragedy and the persistence of myth in memory (1:25).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performances on Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day)

results.web_description: Joy Behar, who for years was one of the stars of the daytime talk show “The View,” takes the stage in this one-woman mixture of autobiography and tried-and-true comic shtick. If you liked her on “The View,” and not everybody did, you’ll like this (1:30).
results.date_time_description: through Dec. 21 (no performance on Thanksgiving Day; added performance on Nov. 26)

results.web_description: “Metamorphosis” is the theme of the latest edition of the Big Apple Circus, now nested at Lincoln Center for the holidays. Considering the intimate scale of this troupe, you could say this production starts modestly, only to spread its wings and soar. The company, now in its 37th year, doesn’t only have impressive animals and breathtaking acrobatic skills; it has a lot of heart, too (2:00).

results.event_name: MoMA PS 1: ‘Bob and Roberta Smith: Art Amnesty’
results.web_description: Bob and Roberta Smith is the cognomen of a British artist who specializes in humorously mocking art institutions and the conventional attitudes they tend to promulgate. The ostensible idea of this show is to give people an opportunity to officially retire from making art and to ceremonially discard works of art they own but no longer want. Unloaded works are displayed along with jazzy signs painted by Mr. Smith on all kinds of surfaces. One proclaims, “Joseph Beuys conclusive proof not everyone is an artist.”

results.event_name: Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Indian: Photography and Jewelry Display
results.web_description: More than 80 black-and-white photographs and vintage postcards from the 1920s to ’60s, featuring the work of the American Indian photographer Horace Poolaw, who died in 1984, are the focus of the exhibition “For a Love of His People,” on view through Feb. 15. His camera is also part of the display, which chronicles American Indian life on the Southern Plains of Oklahoma. Another exhibition, “Glittering World: Navajo Jewelry of the Yazzie Family,” a collection of 300 pieces of jewelry, runs through Jan. 10.
results.venue_name: Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian
results.date_time_description: daily from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; until 8 p.m. on Thursdays; closed Christmas Day

results.event_name: New York Transit Museum: ‘Spanning the Narrows: The Verrazano Bridge at 50’
results.web_description: Photographs, maps, drawings, models and other archival materials related to the construction of the bridge (including correspondence from Robert Moses, who oversaw the project) are part of this exhibition commemorating its 50th anniversary.
results.price: $7, $5 for 2 to 17 and 62+, free for members and on Wednesdays for those 62+
results.date_time_description: Tuesdays through Fridays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Christmas Day and New Year's Day

results.web_description: This interesting though occasionally long-winded one-man show (written by and starring Tom Dugan) looks at the life of the Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal (1:30).

The lines between pleasure and pain keep blurring in this ecstasy-drunk British import from the Kneehigh Theater (“Brief Encounter”), which retells the tragedy of its doomed-to-love title characters. Long stretches of Emma Rice’s ever-surprising, musically eclectic production feel like a giddy party. Then before you know it, you’ve been ambushed by a sorrow that makes your eyes sting (2:15).

Ayad Akhtar’s latest drama, about the dark connections between money and terrorism, finds an American banker held hostage by Islamic militants in Pakistan. Justin Kirk gives a canny performance as the Citibank exec who tries to keep himself alive by helping his captors work the global markets (2:00).
results.cross_street: between Second Avenue and the Bowery
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performances on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, with an added performance on  Dec. 22)

results.web_description: (in previews; opens on Jan. 15) What happens in Vegas stays in Vegas. What happens in New Jersey? Not so much. After a successful run at the Paper Mill Playhouse, this musical adaptation of the 1992 film convinced its producers to take a gamble and bring it to Broadway. The director Gary Griffin deals in Rob McClure and Brynn O’Malley as a pair of young romancers, with Tony Danza as a wily kingpin.
results.date_time_description: continuing (no performances on Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve; added performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: On the heels of her acclaimed show “Rock Bottom,” Ms. Everett, a powerhouse comedian and cabaret performer, returns with a night of love songs and tender moments.
results.cross_street: between East Fourth Street and Astor Place

results.event_name: New Museum: ‘Chris Ofili: Night and Day’
results.web_description: This intoxicating midcareer survey presents six distinct bodies of paintings and drawings, as well as a few sculptures, tracing a remarkable development. It reveals an artist restlessly pushing his art to new extremes of decorativeness and harshness, darkness and threat, funky extravagance and suavity. Painting itself undergoes several transmutations. Race, religion, pop culture and nature are touched on. Color triumphs in several forms. The art is never shortchanged.

results.event_name: El Museo del Barrio: ‘Marisol: Sculptures and Works on Paper’
results.web_description: This 30-piece survey, organized by the Memphis Brooks Museum of Art, makes virtues of the artist’s restlessness and eclecticism. It includes her underappreciated works on paper alongside sculptural tableaus that combine woodcarving and assemblage (for instance, “The Family,” a funky nativity scene from 1969 that is dominated by a neon-haloed, heavily bedazzled Virgin). It could have done more, however, to explore her Latin American folk-art influences and Venezuelan roots, which deserve at least as much scrutiny as her ties to American Pop art.

Mr. Hartung’s 60-minute video is a captivating, hectic montage of animation, found news footage and music. It’s supposed to be an interpretation of the Old Testament, but except for a lovely musical version of Psalm 23 sung by the British boy band the Choirboys, it’s hard to discern specific biblical references. But there is a majestic quality to the whole as it ranges from real-world images of violence to nearly abstract passages of hallucinogenic beauty.

results.event_name: Jewish Museum: ‘Helena Rubinstein: Beauty Is Power’
results.web_description: The first museum show devoted to the life and art collection of the cosmetics magnate Helena Rubinstein is a master class in modernism-as-marketing — one that comes with a strong female perspective on 20th-century visual culture. It shows us how Rubinstein adapted Cubism, Surrealism and other avant-garde art and design movements for her personal brand, highlighting new and different standards of beauty and exhorting women to control their own images through makeup and grooming. Mixing biography, business, art, fashion and décor, it recreates rooms from Rubinstein’s salons and reassembles parts of her diverse collection, which included African, pre-Columbian and Oceanic artworks.

In the late 19th century, the building that housed the Drawing Center was home to the Positive Motion Loom Company. The center’s current group show invokes that history in, among other works, a lively installation and performance by Anne Wilson. Titled “To Cross (Walking New York),” it features black-clad dancers who wrap the gallery’s four central columns in brightly colored crisscrossing threads, essentially turning them into a giant loom.

results.event_name: Museum of Modern Art: ‘Henri Matisse: The Cut-Outs’
results.web_description: A popular image of the elderly Matisse is of a serene, bespectacled pasha propped up in bed and surrounded by doves and flowers. But in the years around 1940, he must have felt he was living a nightmare. He and his wife of more than four decades separated. He underwent debilitating surgery for cancer. During World War II, he fled south to Nice, only to have that city threatened with bombardment. Through everything, he worked on. It is this Matisse — the invalid, insomniac, night-worker and waking dreamer — we meet in the marvelous, victory-lap show that has arrived in New York from London, trailing light, praise and lines around the block.
results.cross_street: between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas

results.event_name: Daniel Gordon: ‘Screen Selections and Still Lifes’
results.web_description: This photographer-sculptor hops back and forth across the analog/digital divide, starting out — in the most innocuous of ways — by searching Google for still lifes. He then prints the results — images of fruits, vegetables and vases — and turns them into three-dimensional photo-sculptures with scissors and glue. Those objects are then arranged on punchy, patterned backdrops, à la Matisse, and photographed. In yet another stage of picture making, the photographs are tweaked through digital editing; colors are changed with Fauvist abandon; and background features — shadows, a studio window — added or erased.

results.event_name: New York Transit Museum Annex: Holiday Train Show
results.web_description: This free annual holiday treat for model train enthusiasts, featuring vintage Lionel trains, is on display in Grand Central Terminal.
results.venue_name: New York Transit Museum Gallery Annex and Store at Grand Central Terminal
results.date_time_description: through Feb. 22. weekdays from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Sundays from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.; starting Dec. 26: from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; closed on Christmas Day and New Year's Day

results.event_name: New York Botanical Garden: Holiday Train Show and ‘Bar Car Night’
results.web_description: Landmarks made of natural materials, including new models of Grand Central Terminal and the garden’s conservatory, are included in this year’s display. And there are, of course, the model trains that whiz by the luxuriant foliage. On Friday and Saturday from 7 to 10 p.m., visitors 21 and older can view the display — the 23rd — while sipping cocktails and listening to jazz during the “Bar Car Night” series, which runs selected days through Jan. 10; admission is $35, $25 for members and reservations are recommended.
results.price: $20 on weekdays, with discounts for 65+, students and children, and $28 on weekends, with the same discounts. A complete breakdown is at the website.
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 19. Tuesdays through Fridays and Sundays from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.; closed Christmas Day; open Dec. 15, 22, and 29; closing at 3 p.m. on Dec. 12 and 24. Bar Car Nights, from 7 to 10 p.m., are Dec. 19-20; Jan. 2-3, and Jan. 9-10; admission is $35, $25 for members and reservations are recommended.

results.event_name: ‘The Amazing Adventures of Harvey and the Princess’
results.web_description: Making Books Sing has changed its name to New York City Children’s Theater, but that doesn’t mean that it isn’t still turning children’s books into innovative musicals. Its latest venture, with score and lyrics by the young people’s pop sensation Laurie Berkner, and a script by Barbara Zinn Krieger, the organization’s artistic director, is an adaptation of “Harvey the Child Mime,” by Loryn Brantz. For ages 3 through 8, the show, closing this weekend, illustrates what happens when one of Harvey’s bits goes a little too well, and the invisible box in which he’s shut himself is treated as a real one. He finds himself on a ship bound for Pink Mountain Island, where he encounters a princess in need of some help.
results.date_time_description: Nov. 15-Dec. 14 at various times. Friday at 11 a.m. and 5 p.m., Saturday and Sunday at 10 a.m. and 2 p.m.

results.event_name: Christopher Williams: ‘For Example: Dix-Huit Leçons Sur la Société Industrielle (Revision 19)’
results.web_description: The idea of photography-as-apparatus has guided Mr. Williams throughout his career. He has analyzed different genres of photography and literally dissected cameras and photographed their components. He resumes that project here, with photographs of bisected camera lenses; a professional show rooster depicted in its trained pose; and a half-submerged cooking pan that riffs on cheery product advertisements. He is not so much altering the program of photography, however, as illustrating and fetishizing it. His images are meticulous and gorgeous, but programmed to seduce rather than transform.

The Irish Repertory Theater’s musical version of the Truman Capote short story is as slight as a popcorn strand, as wispy as tinsel. A tale of a boy’s attachment to his childlike cousin (Alice Ripley), it is an exercise in holiday nostalgia. In cold blood? More like in warm batter (1:30).
results.cross_street: between Irving Place and Park Avenue
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performances on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and New Year's Day)

results.web_description: Rockettes, angels and magi, dancing teddy bears and a 3-D aerial tour in Santa’s sleigh — this show is as much a celebration of the city as of the holidays (1:30).

(in previews; opens on Dec. 15) A lot of playwrights can’t be bothered with the flyover district, but that’s where the MacArthur-winning writer Samuel D. Hunter lives. Artistically, anyway. In this new play, directed by Davis McCallum and set in small-town Idaho, T.R. Knight plays the lonely manager of an Olive Garden-ish restaurant, unsoothed by unlimited breadsticks.
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performances on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, New Year's Eve and New Year's Day, with added performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Seven talented tricksters are drowning in a sea of cheese in this overproduced, overblown magic show (2:00).
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performances on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and New Year's Day, with additional performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: This two-hander by Kate Robin, who works on the Showtime series “The Affair,” is about a man and woman, married to others, who fall into an unexpected intimacy after meeting while watching over their respective children in a kiddie ball pit. It’s amusing enough, and even a little insightful by the end, but the “she” half (played by Danielle Slavick) is one of those people who rant about everything — climate change, iPads, gluten — which undercuts the piece’s credibility; that’s the kind of stranger not many people would want to get to know better (1:30).
results.date_time_description: through Dec. 14, with a holiday hiatus from Nov. 24-Dec. 1

results.event_name: Museum of Modern Art: ‘Sturtevant: Double Trouble’
results.web_description: Among the first things you see in MoMA’s taut, feisty retrospective of the American artist Elaine Sturtevant is work by far better known figures: Joseph Beuys, Jasper Johns, Marcel Duchamp. In each case, however, the pieces are by Ms. Sturtevant herself, who spent much of a long career adopting and adapting the art and styles of others to create a body of work entirely her own, one which raises questions about the value of art, about the hows and whys of producing it, and about the degrees to which quasi-replication can be an exercise in flattery, parody, objectivity, originality and love.
results.cross_street: between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas

results.event_name: Holiday Markets at Union Square, Bryant Park and Columbus Circle
results.web_description: These outdoor markets are in full swing. Open through Christmas Eve, the market in Union Square Park, bordered by Park Avenue South and Broadway, from East 14th to 17th Streets, is open weekdays from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; and Sundays from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. More information: urbanspacenyc.com. In Midtown, the Holiday Shops will be open through Jan. 4 in Bryant Park, at Avenue of the Americas and 40th Street. Hours: weekdays from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; and Sundays from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.  More details: bryantpark.org. And farther uptown, the stalls of the Columbus Circle Holiday Market will run through Christmas Eve. Hours are Mondays through Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. and Sundays from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.; urbanspacenyc.com/columbus-circle-holiday-market.
results.date_time_description: Nov. 21 to Dec. 24. Weekdays from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; and Sundays from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.

results.event_name: Holiday Markets at Grand Central Terminal and in SoHo
results.web_description: These indoor markets are in full swing. In Vanderbilt Hall at Grand Central Terminal, the shops will remain up through Christmas Eve; grandcentralterminal.com. In SoHo, a holiday pop-up boutique will be open through Christmas Eve at 150 Wooster Street, near Houston Street; sohocollectiveny.com.
results.date_time_description: Nov. 21-Dec. 24. Mondays through Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Sundays from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.;  Dec. 24 from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.

results.event_name: American Museum of Natural History: Origami Holiday Tree
results.web_description: With the “Night at the Museum” films as this year’s theme, the holiday tree will include origami versions of figures from that movie series — including Theodore Roosevelt, a Tyrannosaurus rex and a capuchin monkey with keys — in addition to other holiday decorations. Visitors can also see how the origami figures are created during demonstrations by museum volunteers.
results.price: suggested admission: $22, $17 for students and 60+, and $12.50 for children 2 to 12
results.date_time_description: Nov. 24-Jan. 11 from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; closed on Christmas Day

results.web_description: Vital Theater Company, which gave eager young audiences “Fancy Nancy: The Musical,” has now returned with a new show starring that inimitable little diva. Based on the book written by Jane O’Connor and illustrated by Robin Preiss Glasser, “Fancy Nancy: Splendiferous Christmas” deals with Nancy’s fancy expectations for the holiday season. With a book by Cara Lustik, music by Randy Klein and lyrics by Matthew Hardy, the production revolves around Nancy’s purchase of a grand decoration for the top of the Christmas tree, and what ensues when her trimming dreams don’t turn out quite as planned.
results.date_time_description: Saturdays and Sundays at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m., with additional performances Dec. 26-Jan. 1.

results.web_description: Joseph Silovsky’s rumpled and wry theatrical brief against the 1927 executions of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti incorporates puppets, a robot and Mr. Silovsky’s customary worn old suitcases. Far from a grim entertainment, this is a clever, complex, handmade show about a legal cause célèbre from long ago (1:30).

results.event_name: ‘On the Other Side of the River’
results.web_description: New Worlds Theater Project, which specializes in English adaptations of Yiddish works, revives this deeply dark and symbolic 1906 play in a production that’s more admirable than enjoyable (1:00).

The famously reclusive painter Albert York (1928-2009) worked on wooden boards and pieces of Masonite rarely exceeding a foot square. With a brushy touch and severely muted colors, he painted landscapes, flowers, cows, dogs and curious allegories in a plain-spoken and at times oddly clumsy yet often exquisitely subtle manner. This beautiful, soul-stirring exhibition presents 37 small paintings dating from 1963 to 1992.

results.event_name: Metropolitan Museum of Art: ‘Bartholomeus Spranger: Splendor and Eroticism in Imperial Prague’
results.web_description: This show is intriguing as much for the story it tells of an eventful and extraordinarily fortunate career as for the works on view, which range from pictures of standard Christian subjects to extravagantly theatrical images of pagan sex and revelry. Working in Prague for the Holy Roman emperor Rudolf II, Bartholomeus Spranger (1546-1611) painted and drew Mannerist-style allegories involving nude and nearly nude gods and goddesses athletically entwined in anatomically improbable positions. His images were copied by expert engravers and disseminated in immense quantities throughout Europe.

Mr. McBride, a genial locomotive of a bassist, is nearing the end of a two-week engagement at the Village Vanguard. For the rest of this week, he’ll lead his ace trio, featuring Christian Sands on piano and Ulysses Owens on drums.
results.price: $25 and $30 cover, with a one-drink minimum

results.web_description: American film’s greatest maverick gets the deluxe treatment, with no fewer than 50 programs in this retrospective. The offerings go well beyond Altman’s canonical works (“MASH,” “Nashville” and the prescient HBO mockumentaries “Tanner ’88” and “Tanner on Tanner”) and the cult favorites (the spellbinding Richard Nixon tour de force “Secret Honor,” the pairing of Harold Pinter and John Travolta in his adaptation of Pinter’s “The Dumb Waiter,” and the severely underrated “Kansas City”) to include 1950s industrial films and episodes of “Bonanza” and “Alfred Hitchcock Presents.” All of this and “Health,” the 1980 political satire that Ronald Reagan called “the world’s worst movie.”
results.venue_name: Museum of Modern Art Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters
results.cross_street: between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas

results.web_description: The holiday season means an avalanche of Nutcrackers around town, most rated G. For those looking for some spice with that sugar, there’s “Nutcracker Rouge,” a baroque-burlesque take on the Christmas classic by Austin McCormick’s Company XIV. The saucy fusion of dance, theater, circus and song takes place in the company’s intimate and opulent new home in NoHo. Cocktails and coquetry abound for those 21 and older.
results.cross_street: between Astor Place and East Fourth Street
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4: Tuesdays through Sundays at 8 p.m., Dec. 20 at 10 p.m., no performances on Dec. 28

results.web_description: If any holiday dance tradition can rival “The Nutcracker,” it’s the Ailey company’s winter season at City Center. This year’s five-week run includes a mix of old and new, including “Odetta,” Matthew Rushing’s tribute to the singer and civil rights activist, and the evergreen “Revelations.”
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4: Tuesdays through Thursdays at 7:30 p.m., Fridays at 8 p.m., Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m., Sundays at 3 and 7:30 p.m.; no performances on Christmas and New Year's Day

results.web_description: “George Balanchine’s the Nutcracker” had its premiere in 1954, and has returned to City Ballet’s repertory every year since. At 60, the holiday classic is still working its charm on balletgoers of all ages. While the principals are sure to be divine, the real stars are the two casts of 50 children from the School of American Ballet.
results.venue_name: David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 3. Fridays at 8 p.m. (with matinees, at 2 p.m., on Dec. 26 and Jan. 2); Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 1 and 5 p.m.; Tuesdays and Wednesdays at 7 p.m. (with matinees, at 2 p.m., on Dec.  17, 23 and 30; 2 p.m. only on Dec. 24 and 30); Thursdays at 7 p.m.; no performances on Christmas and New Year's Day, with added performances, at 7 p.m., on Dec. 22 and 29

results.web_description: There is much to recommend in the Met’s intriguing new production of this Mozart opera, which updates the story to 1930s Spain, starting with the revealing and kinetic performances the director Richard Eyre drew from an appealing, youthful cast when the production opened the season, with James Levine conducting. It’s back, though with a new conductor, the eminent Edo de Waart, and a new cast of popular artists, including Erwin Schrott as Figaro, Danielle de Niese as Susanna, Mariusz Kwiecien as Count Almaviva and Rachel Willis-Sorensen as the Countess. The rotating set, a matrix of ornate, circular towers, is dark, chilly and imposing, the one drawback of this production.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 12 and 15 at 7:30 p.m.; Dec. 20 at noon

results.event_name: Italian American Museum: Neapolitan Crèche Display and Talk
results.web_description: The Neapolitan Crèche, a display of figures depicting the birth of Jesus, is a centuries-old holiday tradition with roots in Naples. The opening of this annual display, on Thursday at 6 p.m., will feature a discussion about that tradition — and its practice here — by Anita Sanseverino, a photographer who has captured images of crèches in Italy and New York City. The presentation will also include a video, with music, of displays in Italy, by Lou Barella, a retired music teacher. On view at the museum through Jan. 11 will be a crèche by Giuseppe and Marco Ferrigno, father-and-son craftsmen in Naples.
results.date_time_description: on view through Jan. 11: Friday through Sunday from noon to 6 p.m.; also Dec. 22-23 and Dec. 29-30 from noon to 6 p.m.; closed Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and New Year’s Day.

results.event_name: Morgan Library & Museum: ‘The Untamed Landscape: Théodore Rousseau and the Path to Barbizon’
results.web_description: Nearly 150 years after his death in 1867, this 19th-century French landscape painter receives his first retrospective in the United States. The show features only drawings and oil studies, but it provides a lucid and revelatory summary of his sensibility and achievement. Rousseau loved nature and drawing with equal passion, and this exhibition is suffused with a determination to explore all that is both ardent and brilliant.

This knockout show introduces more than a dozen works  by this ever-inventive German artist’s series of 20 painted in the mid-1990s on sparkling new patterned awning canvas. The tensions and collusions between the brightly striped or floral fabrics and the darker, quasi-expressionistic paint handling are elegant, dynamic and wry. Made a decade earlier, the series would have been a high point of 1980s painting instead of ingenious summations.

(performances start on Dec. 10) The composer Gabriel Kahane can find inspiration in almost anything — Anne Carson’s poetic fictions, Craigslist ads, the Brooklyn Bridge. For this show, part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival and directed by directed by John Tiffany (“The Glass Menagerie,” “Once”), he’s penned songs inspired by 10 addresses in Los Angeles and characters who might have resided there.
results.venue_name: Harvey Theater, Brooklyn Academy of Music

results.web_description: (performances start on Dec. 10) In 2001, the New York debut of this captivating 1999 play introduced audiences to the muscular, lyrical, fiercely comedic voice of the Irish writer Mark O’Rowe. Now they’ll hear it again. This Dublin-set script is composed of intertwined monologues from rival tough guys. This time around one actor, Tom Vaughan-Lawlor, plays both of them.
results.venue_name: Fishman Space, Fisher Building, Brooklyn Academy of Music

results.web_description: Kristine Haruna Lee’s lively, haphazard play about a young woman (the delightful Erin Markey) on a vague mission whirls together Greek mythology, daytime TV, lesbian pulp fiction and F.T. Marinetti’s Futurist manifesto. It is a show full of impulses and ideas, though without much of a story. But under Jordan Fein’s direction, the gender queer jumble is enthusiastically performed (1:30).

Chekhov’s classic has been modernized by the young British playwright Anya Reiss, and as performed by the Bedlam troupe, directed by Eric Tucker, this loose-limbed production can feel a bit like a thoughtful, generous spirited acting class. But it has an easygoing accessibility that suggests there is no reason to be afraid of Anton Chekhov. Andrus Nichols is a first-rate Masha (2:20).
results.date_time_description: running in repertory with "Sense & Sensibility" through Dec. 20

results.web_description: (in previews; opens on Dec. 14) When Duncan Macmillan’s comedy debuted at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in August, The Guardian called it “one of the funniest plays you’ll ever see about depression.” Jonny Donahoe plays a youngster trying to cheer his suicidal mother with a list of all that’s good in the world, including roller coasters, otters and the color yellow.
results.date_time_description: through March 29 (no performance on Christmas Day)

results.web_description: The tenor saxophonist Jimmy Greene just released a poignant and deeply personal album, “Beautiful Life,” dedicated to the memory of his daughter, who was among the victims of the Sandy Hook shooting of 2012. The album features a number of vocalists, including Kurt Elling and Javier Colon — but for this engagement Mr. Greene seems likely to focus more on the instrumental side, with a rhythm section consisting of the bassist Luke Sellick and the drummer Jimmy MacBride.
results.cross_street: between Lexington Avenue and Park Avenue South
results.date_time_description: Dec. 11-13 at 7:30 and 10 p.m., with an 11:45 p.m. set on Dec. 12-13

results.web_description: A therapy session and a stand-up routine walk into a bar, take a few shots, and start dancing on the counter. That might give you some sense of the experience — wacky and a bit self-indulgent — of “Too Much Too Soon Mr. Zuccolo,” the latest in a series by Greg Zuccolo. He shares the bill with Animals Performance Group, presenting an absurdist work in progress about corporate negligence and the coming financial apocalypse.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 11-13 at 8 p.m., Dec. 14 at 3 p.m.

results.web_description: It’s been two years since the London-based choreographer Russell Maliphant, known for his myriad stylistic influences, visited New York. Then, he presented work inspired by Rodin; this time his inspirations are Nijinsky and Béjart, the respective muses of the solos “Afterlight (Part One)” and “Two,” both of which make inventive use of Michael Hulls’s lighting. The newest work on the program is “Still Current,” a compilation of solos, duets and trios in which Mr. Maliphant performs.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 10 at 7:30 p.m., Dec. 11-13 at 8 p.m., Dec. 14 at 2 p.m.

results.web_description: The Tchaikovsky music remains but the ballet dancers are out. In their place, a troupe of poppers, lockers, b-boys and b-girls interpret the classic holiday score. “The Hip Hop Nutcracker” is the brainchild of the director and choreographer Jennifer Weber of the all-girl hip-hop crew Decadancetheatre and Mike Fitelson, who’s credited with adapting the tale to the streets of New York. DJ Boo provides the hip-hop interludes and the legendary rapper Kurtis Blow serves as guest M.C.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 7 at 6 p.m.; Dec. 13 at 1 p.m.

results.web_description: To gird ourselves against an overwhelming sense of helplessness in the face of riots, wars and disease, we resort to satire, parody and jokes. The choreographer Keely Garfield wonders if this doesn’t worsen the condition as much as it soothes it. So “Wow,” her latest work, is meant as a dance without irony or cleverness — in her words, “a truly sincere act.”

results.event_name: Ann Lislegaard: ‘Oracles, Owls … Some Animals Never Sleep’
results.web_description: This elegant show presents three intriguing pieces based on famous works of science fiction. “The Flower from Weena” is a white, geometric flower represents a key element in H.G. Wells’s 1895 novel “The Time Machine.” A two-screen video of a digitally animated owl was inspired by Philip K. Dick’s novel “Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?” and on the movie “Blade Runner.” A mysterious, five-minute digitally animated film is called “Dobaded,” a word encountered in Kawamata Chiaki’s novel “Death Sentences.”

results.event_name: The Month in Cabaret: Stacey Kent, Marcos Valle and Michael Feinstein
results.web_description: The jazz singer Stacey Kent’s recent collaboration with Marcos Valle, the Brazilian songwriter, arranger, instrumentalist and singer,  on an album celebrating the 50th anniversary of his music career, underscores Ms. Kent’s passionate, longstanding attachment to bossa nova and samba. The two have been performing at Birdland this week with a Brazilian band, featuring Jesse Sadoc on trumpet and flugelhorn, Marcelo Martins on saxophone and flute, Alberto Continentino on acoustic bass and Renato Massa on drums. The saxophonist Jim Tomlinson, Ms. Kent’s musical partner and husband, is also appearing with them. Ms. Kent and Mr. Valle’s Birdland engagement will be followed on Tuesday by Michael Feinstein’s annual Christmas show, “Happy Holidays: Swinging With the Big Band,” in which he will return to his two-fisted Sinatra mode. This spring Mr. Feinstein will make the renovated basement under the club’s main room his New York cabaret headquarters.
results.price: Marcos Valle & Stacey Kent: $45, with a $10 minimum; Michael Feinstein: $60 to $250, with a $10 minimum
results.date_time_description: Marcos Valle & Stacey Kent: Dec. 9-13 at 8:30 and 11 p.m.; Michael Feinstein: Dec. 16-20 and 23-27 at 8:30 p.m.

results.date_time_description: Laura Osnes: Dec. 9, 12-13 and 15; Liz Callaway: Dec. 22 to 27, except Christmas Day

results.event_name: The Month in Cabaret: Stacey Kent, Marcos Valle and Michael Feinstein
results.web_description: The jazz singer Stacey Kent’s recent collaboration with Marcos Valle, the Brazilian songwriter, arranger, instrumentalist and singer,  on an album celebrating the 50th anniversary of his music career, underscores Ms. Kent’s passionate, longstanding attachment to bossa nova and samba.
