results.date_time_description: Steve Tyrell: through Dec. 31; Tuesdays to Thursdays at 8:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 8:45 and 10:45 p.m.

results.event_name: ‘Dr. Seuss’ How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The Musical’
results.web_description: The Grinch may be second only to Scrooge as a literary symbol of those who would deny the holiday spirit. And like Scrooge, he spends a lot of time being converted onstage. He’s come back to New York for a brief run of this musical by Mel Marvin and Timothy Mason, who have adapted Dr. Seuss’s classic tale of the Grinch’s attempt to deprive the good citizens of Who-ville of their Christmas. In this version, Max, the Grinch’s beleaguered dog, narrates.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 5-28 at various times. Dec. 12 at 11 a.m. and 7 p.m.; Dec. 13 at 1, 4 and 7 p.m.; Dec. 14 at 1 and 4 p.m.; Dec. 18 at 7 p.m.

results.web_description: The title may seem French, but the show is unmistakably Asian: This two-hour production heralds the return of the Golden Dragon Acrobats, from Hebei Province, China, to the New Victory Theater, where they first wowed young audiences in 2005. And don’t expect ordinary handsprings and somersaults. This troupe’s members specialize in the extreme, like balancing on one hand on a stack of chairs or doing ballet moves while perched on another person’s shoulders. They’ll offer a lion dance, too.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 5-Jan. 4 at various times. Dec. 13 at 2 and 7 p.m., and Dec. 14 at noon and 5 p.m.

results.web_description: You can sometimes find junk in a swamp, but in the one conjured by this shadow puppet show, the creatures are rubbish, too. Jeff Achtem, of Melbourne, Australia, uses ordinary household stuff to create his characters, which include a snail, a crocodile, a mouse, a snake, birds and a grumpy old man who interacts with them all. (In the finale, audience members are given 3-D glasses to complete their swamp immersion.) This Saturday and on Dec. 21 and 27, Mr. Achtem will also give workshops after the 11 a.m. show to teach children how to make their own shadow puppets from castoff and recycled goods.
results.price: $45 for show tickets; workshops, which are $20, can be reserved by calling 212-243-6262 or by emailing boxoffice@barrowstreettheatre.com.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 6-Jan. 4 at various times. Dec. 13 at 11 a.m. and 5 p.m.; Dec. 14 at 5 p.m.; Dec. 15 at 7:30 p.m.; Dec. 18 at 9:30 p.m.

results.web_description: The clever feline hero of this fairy tale is quite a swashbuckler, but in this hourlong version, closing this weekend, he sings arias, too. Presented by Gotham Chamber Opera and the Tectonic Theater Project (and directed by Moisés Kaufman), '‘Puss in Boots’' features singers performing Xavier Montsalvatge’s 1946 score. Puss and the other characters are incarnated in oversize, bunraku-style puppets from the Blind Summit Theater in London, which is producing this English-language revival, along with El Museo del Barrio and Works & Process at the Guggenheim Museum.
results.venue_name: El Teatro at El Museo del Barrio
results.date_time_description: Dec. 6-14 at various times. Dec. 12 at 7 p.m.; Dec. 13 at 2 and 7 p.m.; Dec. 14 at 2 p.m.

results.web_description: Participants in this tour can get a history lesson and a taste of Lower East Side’s Dominican, Jewish, Italian and Chinese enclaves through fare from local shops and markets.
results.price: $25, $20 for students and 65+, food included, reservation required
results.date_time_description: Dec. 14 at 1 p.m., Dec. 18 at 11 a.m.

results.web_description: Like aspiring fashion designers on “Project Runway,” 56 artists and designers face the unconventional challenge of making wreaths out of sponges, keys, Smarties, forged steel, insect specimens and other outré materials for the 32nd annual Wreath Interpretations exhibition.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 5-Jan. 7; Monday through Friday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.

results.web_description: Organized by the saxophonist and club owner Ilhan Ersahin, this East Village marathon features a range of improvised music, both at Nublu and the nearby Studio 151. The offerings include Penn Station, a group featuring the bassist James Genus, at 11 p.m. on Dec. 10, and a midnight set on Dec. 11 with the guitarists Marco Cappelli and Marc Ribot and the pianist Shoko Nagai.

Brett Davis and Sally Burtnick celebrate the first birthday of their monthly comedy show (which remains unconnected to the titular actor). Performers include Brian McCann, Chris Gethard, Jo Firestone, Josh Rabinowitz, Phoebe Robinson, John F. O’Donnell, Ana Fabrega, and the sketch duo Good Cop Great Cop.
John Lutz and Scott Adsit, “30 Rock” alumni, reunite for an evening of long-form improv.
Mehran Khaghani kicks off his new weekly stand-up show with a powerhouse lineup, including Janeane Garofalo, Eugene Mirman, Jen Kirkman and Gary Gulman.

Mr. Torres is one of the city’s most intriguing young comedians. This show, part of Ars Nova’s Showgasm series, promises sketches, short films and stand-up, addressing themes such as “otherness” and “Tilda Swintoness.”
Mr. St. Germain hosts this vaguely seasonal show, with performances from Brooks Wheelan, Jared Logan, Kevin Barnett, Jacqueline Novak and the comedy duo Team Submarine.

Luis J. Gomez and Adrienne Iapalucci host this inventive twist on the stand-up show, inviting two comedians onstage at the same time to perform. The duos will include Jen Kirkman and Dave Hill; Jessica Kirson and Rachel Feinstein; and Rory Albanese and Aaron Berg.

A 20-year veteran of the stand-up scene, Mr. Gulman is finally being recognized as one of the country’s strongest comedians. Now he’s celebrating with his aptly titled “It’s About Time” tour. This vivid storyteller — who turns conventional premises, such as a trip to Trader Joe’s, into enthralling, epic tales — will be supported by Joe List at these shows.

Brooklyn Comedy Festival returns for a night of seasonal comedy, with appearances from Mark Normand, Michelle Wolf, Jared Logan, Kyle Ayers and possibly Father Christmas. The show is also a fund-raiser, presented in conjunction with New York Cares and Homefront Hugs. Audience members can bring donations of winter coats or supplies for care packages for active military personnel.

The good news for audiences at Todd Michael’s satirical mash-up of old Hollywood movies, Christmas-related and otherwise, is that an exorcism is performed onstage. The bad news is that the play, directed by Lawrence Lesher, falls flat much of the time. Its would-be madcap nature means that it dashes off in multiple directions. Sometimes this works. More often, it doesn’t (1:30).

(previews start on Dec. 11; opens on Jan. 8) Josef Stalin didn’t like it. Will you? The Atlantic Theater Company offers Moira Buffini’s adaptation of Nikolai Erdman’s “The Suicide,” a play that was banned in Soviet Russia. Under Neil Pepe’s direction, Joey Slotnick stars as a depressed man bent on self-slaughter, and Jeanine Serralles is his wearied wife.
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 18 (no performances on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and New Year's Eve, with added performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.web_description: Sweet and fusty, Clare Beecher Kummer’s 1920 comedy centers on a moneyed chap who insists on starring in “Hamlet” before resigning himself to stewardship of the family air-brake business. Though Kummer satirizes passé performance styles and actorly fussiness and the production includes some droll props and costumes, the jest is not exactly infinite (2:30).

Jeff Achtem’s mostly wordless, largely wondrous and fairly repulsive puppet play centers on a despicable dude who cruises the bayou torturing various small animals. It’s a nasty story, but there’s real virtuosity in the telling. Under his flailing fingers, unlikely puppets — made from found and scavenged materials — become all manner of flora and fauna (1:00).

results.event_name: ‘On a Stool at the End of the Bar’
results.web_description: In Robert Callely’s overstuffed new drama, set in the 1980s, a family’s tranquility is blown to smithereens when Tony (Timothy John Smith) discovers that his longtime girlfriend, Chris (Antoinette Thornes), used to be a man. Michael Parva’s calm direction, and Mr. Smith’s sensitive performance lower the play’s high emotional pitch, but Chris’s pain and passion never feel genuine (2:00).

results.event_name: ‘A Christmas Carol, Oy! Hanukkah, Merry Kwanzaa’
results.web_description: The Czechoslovak-American Marionette Theater has done enchanting work in the past, but this marionette show has too many pointed anachronisms and not enough warmth (1:00).
results.cross_street: between Second Avenue and the Bowery

results.event_name: ‘Not the Messiah (He’s a Very Naughty Boy)’
results.web_description: (performances start on Dec. 15) As Monty Python noted in the 1979 film “Life of Brian,” the meek have had a hard time of it. The brash members of that comedy troupe, however, are doing very well for themselves. Now Eric Idle of Monty Python fame, aided by the composer John Du Prez, has transformed “Life of Brian” into a comic oratorio. The Collegiate Chorale’s two-night performance of this work at Carnegie Hall includes solo numbers from Victoria Clark, Marc Kudisch and Lauren Worsham.

(performances start on Dec. 18) “Les Misérables” fans can feel that much less miserable now that the lyricist and librettist Alain Boublil of that show is debuting his new play at 59E59 Theaters. Directed by Graciela Daniele and starring Mr. Boublil’s wife, Marie Zamora, the show centers on a French chanteuse and a New York musician who spend a rainy night trading classic tunes.
results.date_time_description: through Jan. 4 (no performance on Christmas Day)

results.web_description: (previews start on Dec. 18; opens on Jan. 22) Do James Lapine and Stephen Sondheim’s woods seem a little less populous? That’s because the Roundabout Theater Company has engaged the acclaimed Fiasco Theater troupe to perform the musical with just 10 actors and a piano. Reviewing the show’s run last year at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, Ben Brantley wrote, “true to form, the Fiasco team continues to keep things simple, the better to bring out the material’s complexity.”
results.venue_name: Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater
results.date_time_description: through March 22 (no performance on Christmas Day)

results.web_description: The Golden Dragon Acrobats, from China, have put together an impressive collection of gravity-defying acts that will impress children and adults alike. Ping Gao’s contortionist routine is the high point (2:00).

(previews start on Dec. 16; opens on Jan. 13) Quantum theory provides the structural conceit for this multiverse romance from the British playwright Nick Payne (“If There Is I Haven’t Found It Yet”) and the director Michael Longhurst. A co-production of Manhattan Theater Club and London’s Royal Court, the play features Jake Gyllenhaal as a beekeeper and Ruth Wilson as his physicist honey.
results.date_time_description: through March 15 (no performances on Christmas Eve, Christmas Day and New Year's Eve, with added performances on Dec. 22 and 29)

results.event_name: ‘Dr. Seuss’ How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The Musical’
results.web_description: The strapping man inside the shaggy green suit is the Tony winner Shuler Hensley, and his Grinch is magnificent, a charismatic showman of a menace who will never truly frighten the children. If only he didn’t have to carry the whole production. His strutting, preening performance is by far the best thing about it (1:30).
results.date_time_description: through Dec. 28 (no performance on Christmas Day)

results.web_description: This 11-week tribute to David Cronenberg, Canada’s reigning master of the disquieting, promises to do a number on what is already a short night’s sleep. (The films screen at midnight each weekend.) Even Mr. Cronenberg’s recent swerves into studio fare (“A History of Violence,” “Eastern Promises”) have shed surprisingly little of the perverse ambition that spurred him to tackle such seemingly unfilmable adaptations as “Naked Lunch” and “Crash.” Midnight staples like “Scanners” (this weekend’s offering) and “Videodrome” (Jan. 1 to 3) are obvious choices, and his 1986 remake of “The Fly” (Dec. 26 to 28) remains an unsurpassed combination of the romantic and the repulsive. The retrospective culminates with a screening of his latest film, “Maps to the Stars,” and the adjoining IFC Center gallery will feature a collection of Mr. Cronenberg’s international movie posters throughout the run.

results.event_name: Best Film Not Playing at a Theater Near You
results.web_description: This cheekily titled series, entering its ninth year, has given visibility to noteworthy films from the festival circuit, among them “An Oversimplification of Her Beauty” and “Frownland.” All but one of this year’s five titles clock in at under 90 minutes, and while Lev Kalman and Whitney Horn’s philosophizing-grad-student satire, “L for Leisure” (Saturday at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 4:15 p.m.), may be this year’s most commercial-sounding title, it would be a shame if Nathan Silver’s “Uncertain Terms” (Friday at 6 p.m. and Sunday at 1:45 p.m.) didn’t find distribution, too. This intimate, ambling drama about a pastoral home for pregnant teenagers packs a miniseries’ worth of regrets, resentment and ignored cellphone calls into 71 minutes while still finding time for a dance sequence to Khia’s “My Neck, My Back.” The directors of these and the other films — “Evaporating Borders,” “Approaching the Elephant” and “The Mend” — will introduce their work.
results.venue_name: Museum of Modern Art Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters
results.cross_street: between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas

results.web_description: Attention, all mystery completists: Here’s a chance to finally see “The Big Sleep” and “The Maltese Falcon.” What’s that? You’ve seen them both a dozen times? Not these versions. Film Forum’s two-week survey of works based on or written by four master pulp writers — Raymond Chandler, Dashiell Hammett, Cornell Woolrich and James M. Cain — includes Howard Hawks’s original, longer cut of “Sleep” and a pre-Code version of “Falcon” that predates the Humphrey Bogart vehicle by a full decade. The better-known works will also be on offer, along with staples like “Rear Window” (adapted from a Woolrich story), the suddenly ubiquitous “The Long Goodbye” and a torrid double bill of “Double Indemnity” and “The Postman Always Rings Twice.”
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue South

results.web_description: The Dallas band the Old 97’s, alternative-country torchbearers since the early ’90s, have long catered to outlaw-rock fans. The band’s spirited lead singer, Rhett Miller, will be hard-pressed not to offer a track or two from the band’s fiery catalog during his second annual holiday music and comedy revue, which will feature Jen Kirkman, Dave Hill and Wyatt Cenac.

results.event_name: Rufus and Martha Wainwright’s Noel Nights
results.web_description: These prodigious musical siblings revive their giddy, glittery collaborative holiday show in New York after a three-year absence. The yuletide offerings will include performances by them, and  several members of their talented folk-pop family: Loudon Wainwright III, Sloan Wainwright and Lucy Wainwright Roche.
results.cross_street: between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue

results.web_description: After failing to hit some crucial notes during a performance of her seasonal staple, “All I Want for Christmas Is You,” at the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree lighting ceremony, Ms. Carey took to Twitter to apologize to her fans. This pop star will have ample time to make amends — and show if she still has the chops to flaunt her multi-octave range — during her unprecedented, six-night holiday residency at the Beacon Theater.

“Basher,” as the prolific British singer-producer Nick Lowe was called in the 1970s, manned the boards for seminal albums by the Replacements, the Damned and others. Long a cult favorite for his own pub-rock releases and deft songwriting — especially the seismic “(What’s So Funny ’Bout) Peace, Love, and Understanding,” lent to his pal Elvis Costello.  For these shows, he offers Christmas standards and original holiday tracks from his 2013 release, “Quality Street: A Seasonal Selection for All the Family.” With Los Straitjackets.

“Basher,” as the prolific British singer-producer Nick Lowe was called in the 1970s, manned the boards for seminal albums by the Replacements, the Damned and others. Long a cult favorite for his own pub-rock releases and deft songwriting — especially the seismic “(What’s So Funny ’Bout) Peace, Love, and Understanding,” lent to his pal Elvis Costello.  For these shows, he offers Christmas standards and original holiday tracks from his 2013 release, “Quality Street: A Seasonal Selection for All the Family.” With Los Straitjackets.

The sweetly yearning soft-pop singer behind the 1990s hits  “Damn, I Wish I Was Your Lover” and “As I Lay Me Down,” as well as a former Roxy Music collaborator, Ms. Hawkins is an undersung purveyor of pop ear worms. She’ll play material from her latest album, “The Crossing.”

This unclassifiable D.J. collective from Washington (made up of Eric Hilton and Rob Garza) draws on disparate and often unpredictable sources: acid jazz, Indian ragas and late-1990s electronica, to name a few. Some of its recent collaborators have included David Byrne, Femi Kuti, Seu Jorge and Anoushka Shankar; for its latest, “Saudade,” released this year, the duo skipped the flashy cameos and revisited its Brazilian bossa nova roots.

A consummate performer, Mr. Timberlake exudes a jovial sense of enthusiasm for all his talents: singing, dancing, comedy, flirting. He continues to tour in support of his grandiose double album, “The 20/20 Experience,” the second half of which was released last fall. One of the singles from that release, the tender “Not a Bad Thing,” was supported by a crowd-sourced video of photos and tweets.

Amid a few years of change that included the decision of his longtime band, the Walkmen, to go on hiatus and his wife’s pregnancy, Mr. Martin funneled his excess rock energy and familial affection into his first solo album. “We’re All Young Together,” released last spring, is a warmly singsong, folk-inflected dash of wholesome family pop. He hosts a holiday show with Kat Edmonson.
results.cross_street: between East Fourth Street and Astor Place

results.event_name: The Month in Cabaret: Laura Osnes, Liz Callaway and Steve Tyrell
results.web_description: High points of this month’s cabaret season include the Broadway singers Laura Osnes and Liz Callaway performing new shows at 54 Below. Steve Tyrell holds forth at Café Carlyle, with his crowd-pleasing show of Brill Building classics, “That Lovin’ Feeling.”
results.date_time_description: Laura Osnes: Dec. 9, 12-13 and 15; Liz Callaway: Dec. 22 to 27, except Christmas Day

results.event_name: The Month in Cabaret: Laura Osnes, Liz Callaway and Steve Tyrell
results.web_description: High points of this month’s cabaret season include the Broadway singers Laura Osnes and Liz Callaway performing new shows at 54 Below. Steve Tyrell holds forth at Café Carlyle, with his crowd-pleasing show of Brill Building classics, “That Lovin’ Feeling.”
results.date_time_description: Steve Tyrell: through Dec. 31; Tuesdays through Thursdays at 8:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 8:45 and 10:45 p.m.

results.web_description: The piano man is kicking up his heels at Madison Square Garden, where he began his open-ended monthly residency in January. The arena is billing him as its fourth franchise — and, at the least, he will give those Las Vegas residencies a run for their money.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 18, Jan. 9, Feb. 18, March 9, April 3 and May 28 at 8 p.m.

results.web_description: The insightful and effervescent pianist Jacky Terrasson has been working regularly in recent months with a rhythm section anchored by Burniss Travis on bass. This weekend he adds the drummer Jonathan Pinson and the percussionist Mauricio Herrera.

Mr. Goldberg, a clarinetist and composer of multivalent interests, has been working on an ambitious project, “Orphic Machine,” inspired by the poetic writings of Allen Grossman. That music will probably make up some part of his presentation here, in a concert featuring the saxophonist Donny McCaslin, the guitarist Steve Cardenas, the bassist Stomu Takeishi and the drummer Tyshawn Sorey.
results.cross_street: between Third Avenue and Nevins Street

results.web_description: Last year Mr. Bey released a magnificent piano-and-vocal album, “The World According to Andy Bey,” that captured his spirit in the best sonic circumstances. His new “Pages From an Imaginary Life” could be seen as a companion album: it finds him once again alone at the piano, singing songbook ballads at a honey drip, and offering epigrammatic soul advice in the form of mystical originals, like “Bad Luck May Be Good Luck” and “All That Glitter’s Not Gold.”
results.cross_street: near Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard
results.price: $50 cover at tables, $30 in the lounge, $25 at the bar

results.web_description: This young pianist has made it his mission to interrogate the folkloric root systems of Afro-Cuban life, often with the percussionist Román Díaz. On his superb album “Mbókò,” Mr. Virelles further enlists two strong bassists and a sharp drummer. For this album-release concert, the bassists are Thomas Morgan and Dezron Douglas, and the drummer is Eric McPherson.

Mr. Stacken is a pianist of rigorous imagination, as he has proved over the last few years with a strict series of home recordings posted to his website; his new album, “Helleborus,” came out of a weekly composition project, though it hardly has the feel of a homework assignment. As on this album-release celebration, it spotlights the loose but well-bonded rapport of a band with the tenor saxophonist Tony Malaby, the bassist Sean Conly and the drummer Tom Rainey.
results.cross_street: between Bleecker and West Fourth Streets

results.web_description: Henry Butler, a New Orleans pianist with a knack for percussive prestidigitation, teamed up with the trumpeter-arranger Steven Bernstein on “Viper’s Drag,” an ebullient jaunt released on the revived Impulse! label. As on the album, they work here with collaborators like the violinist Charlie Burnham and the trombonist Curtis Fowlkes.
results.cross_street: between Lexington Avenue and Park Avenue South
results.date_time_description: Dec. 18-21 at 7:30 and 10 p.m., with an 11:45 p.m. set Dec. 19 and 20

results.web_description: Mr. Malaby, a tenor saxophonist equally capable of focused tension and wild abandon, works with two groups this weekend, each a representative outlet. On Friday he leads a quintet with Christopher Hoffman on guitar, Dan Peck on tuba, Eivind Opsvik on bass and Billy Mintz on drums. On Saturday he presents a version of his Adobe project, with Mr. Mintz and the bassist John Hébert.
results.cross_street: between Bleecker and West Fourth Streets

results.web_description: Mr. Botti, whose adult-pop savvy and controlled but brooding trumpet sound have made him a global superstar, descends on the Blue Note each year around this time for an extended engagement. This is his 10th annual run, and as usual he brings a slick but substantial band, and the clout to welcome the occasional unbilled celebrity guest.
results.cross_street: between Macdougal Street and Avenue of the Americas
results.price: many tables are sold out, $40 at the bar, with a $5 minimum

results.web_description: Mr. Douglas, a trumpeter, and Mr. Caine, a pianist, have logged many bandstand hours over the years, but on their new album, “Present Joys,” they lock into a more conversational mode. Inspired by the music of the Sacred Harp tradition, it’s an album of duologue that manages to be at once intimate, soulful and irrepressibly buoyant.

In what has become a welcome holiday tradition, the drummer Matt Wilson reconvenes the band from his 2010 album, “Matt Wilson’s Christmas Tree-O” — a rugged but approachable trio with Jeff Lederer on reeds and Paul Sikivie on bass — for a two-night stand full of cheer.
results.cross_street: between Lexington Avenue and Park Avenue South

results.web_description: The veteran drummer and educator Michael Carvin has a robust new album, “Flash Forward,” featuring the same band that appears here, with Keith Loftis on saxophone, Yayoi Ikawa on piano and Jansen Cinco on bass.

Duke Ellington and Billy Strayhorn’s suave arrangement of “The Nutcracker Suite,” recorded in 1960, forms the crux of this second annual holiday program, with musical direction by the Ellington specialist David Berger. Along with a 16-piece band and a gospel choir, it will feature the soprano Priscilla Baskerville, the tap dancer Jason Samuels Smith, students from Dance Theater of Harlem and narration by the actor Norm Lewis.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 13 at 3 and 8 p.m.; Dec. 14 at 3 p.m.

results.web_description: Allison Miller, a drummer of propulsive adaptability, leads a slightly modified version of her dynamic Boom Tic Boom band, with Myra Melford on piano, Jenny Scheinman on violin, Kirk Knuffke on cornet and Todd Sickafoose on bass; the clarinetist Ben Goldberg joins them as a featured guest.
results.cross_street: between Third Avenue and Nevins Street

results.web_description: As per tradition, Jazz at Lincoln Center’s holiday concert features its house orchestra, led by its artistic director, Wynton Marsalis. For the second straight year it will also shine a spotlight on Cécile McLorin Salvant, a savvy young jazz vocalist who has never met an old-fashioned melody she couldn’t reanimate with style.
results.venue_name: Rose Theater, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center
results.date_time_description: Dec. 18-20 at 8 p.m., with a 2 p.m. show on Dec. 20

results.web_description: Jeff (Tain) Watts is an intelligent steamroller of a drummer, and over the last decade he has proved himself an astute bandleader and composer. For this weeklong run at the Village Vanguard, he features the saxophonist Ravi Coltrane, on whose albums he has memorably played.
results.price: $25 and $30 cover, with a one-drink minimum

results.web_description: A bebop veteran who has stayed true to form, the alto saxophonist Charles McPherson appears at the helm of a strong, supportive band, with Steve Nelson on vibraphone, Yotam Silberstein on guitar, Kiyoshi Kitagawa on bass and Chuck McPherson, his son, on drums.
results.venue_name: Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center
results.price: $40 and $45 cover, with a $10 minimum; $25 for students

results.web_description: Franco Zeffirelli’s overwrought, perennially popular production of Puccini’s opera concludes its fall run at the house with Angela Gheorghiu as Mimì, Michael Fabiano as Rodolfo and Susanna Phillips as Musetta. Riccardo Frizza conducts.

The Metropolitan Opera has revived its holiday staple,  Humperdinck’s take on the classic fairy tale. Richard Jones’s 2007 production, translated into English by David Pountney, focuses on hunger, featuring giant chefs, a table-waiting fish and a giant mouth dispensing cake. In the first of seven performances, Andrew Davis conducts the charming soprano Aleksandra Kurzak (Gretel) and the mezzo Christine Rice (Hansel), supported by Robert Brubaker (the Witch), Michaela Martens (Gertrude) and Dwayne Croft (Peter).
results.date_time_description: Dec. 18, 27 and Jan. 8  at 7:30 p.m.; Dec. 23 and 30 at 11 a.m.; Jan. 1 at 6 p.m.

results.web_description: Otto Schenk’s lovingly traditional 1993 production of this Wagner work has returned to the Metropolitan Opera, and  this run will be its last. When the opera is next presented, during the 2019-20 season, it will be in a staging by Stefan Herheim introduced at the Salzburg Festival in 2013. For this revival, the veteran bass-baritone James Morris, who turns 68 next month, saved the day by taking over the role of the shoemaker and master singer Hans Sachs when the scheduled singer  withdrew. Mr. Morris’s voice may be a little worn and leathery these days, but he absolutely is the modest, wise and beloved Sachs, singing with authority and character. Other standouts are the superb tenor Johan Botha as the restless knight Walther and the fine soprano Annette Dasch as Eva, the young woman Walther falls for. James Levine is the conductor. (Michael Volle takes over the role of Sachs for the Dec. 13 performance, which is a Live in HD broadcast.)
results.date_time_description: Dec. 13 at noon; Dec. 17, 20 and 23 at 6 p.m.

results.web_description: Just in time for the holidays, Gotham Chamber Opera revives its dazzling, family-friendly production of Xavier Montsalvatge’s unjustly overlooked gem of a chamber opera based on the fairy tale “Puss in Boots.” Evening performances are sung in the original Spanish; matinees in English. All feature stunning bunraku puppetry and a winning cast of young singers accompanied by the company’s orchestra under the direction of Neal Goren.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 11-12 at 7 p.m.; Dec. 13 at 2 and 7 p.m.; Dec. 14 at 2 p.m.

results.web_description: Anchored by a clock that ticks by with Violetta’s life, this Willy Decker production is a starkly beautiful, modern reconception of Verdi’s classic. The Latvian soprano Marina Rebeka, who has previously appeared as Donna Anna in “Don Giovanni,” takes on the role of Violetta. Stephen Costello sings opposite as Alfredo, with Quinn Kelsey as Germont. The classy Verdian Marco Armiliato conducts.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 16 and 19 at 8 p.m.; Dec. 22, 30 and Jan. 7 at 7:30 p.m.; Dec. 27 at 1 p.m.; Jan. 10 at 8:30 p.m.

results.web_description: Here’s another chance to catch a “Messiah” — one performed by these forces every year at Carnegie Hall since 1961 — and to bid adieu to Andrew Megill, who will be making his last appearance as music director of the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra. Rebecca Mariman, Emily Marvosh, Eric Rieger and David Newman make up the quartet of soloists.

This impressive ensemble has won a loyal following for inventive programs, devised by Clara Longstreth, the group’s longtime conductor, that combine new and old music and unusual works in fresh ways. The chorus’s holiday season program, “Sing With the Spirit,” is typically enticing, with works from Schütz, Bach, Poulenc, Randall Thompson, Daniel Pinkham and Kirke Mechem. A reception, with caroling, will follow the concert.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 12 at 8 p.m.; Dec. 14 at 4 p.m.

results.web_description: Another new prodigy on the violin? In the latest in the Young Concert Artists series, this 18-year-old takes on a daunting program of Beethoven’s Violin Sonata No. 8 (Op. 30, No. 3), Ravel’s Sonata in G, Bartok’s Sonata for Solo Violin and Franz Waxman’s paraphrase on “Carmen.”

The invaluable Peoples’ Symphony Concerts presents one of the leading quartets of the old guard, reinvigorated in the past few years by the arrival of two first-rate new members, in a program of works by Haydn and Berg, along with a Schubert quartet, “Death and the Maiden.”
The storied Vienna Boys Choir rings in the season with a program of holiday classics, Austrian folk songs and popular tunes.

results.event_name: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center
results.web_description: The Society’s Baroque music festival continues with complete performances of Bach’s festive Brandenburg Concertos played by an array of fine musicians, including the violinists Benjamin Beilman, Sean Lee and Daniel Phillips and two members of the Emerson String Quartet, the violist Lawrence Dutton and the cellist Paul Watkins.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 12 and 16 at 7:30 p.m.; Dec. 14 at 5 p.m.

results.web_description: Dvorak is in the spotlight this month during the Philharmonic’s mini festival. On Friday and Saturday, Christoph von Dohnanyi, a noted Dvorak interpreter, conducts the “New World” Symphony and the Piano Concerto, with Martin Helmchen as soloist. On Sunday afternoon, the New York Philharmonic Brass and Percussion Ensemble offers a program of holiday selections, conducted by Philip Smith, its former principal trumpet. And yes, it’s “Messiah” season already: starting on Tuesday, and continuing through next Saturday, Gary Thor Wedow conducts Handel’s perennial favorite, with soloists including the countertenor Iestyn Davies.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 12-13 at 8 p.m.; Dec. 14 at 3 p.m.; Dec.16-18 and 20 at 7:30 p.m.; Dec. 19 at 2 p.m.

results.web_description: This American pianist makes his New York recital debut in the Frick’s intimate music room. His program will feature Schubert’s “Wanderer” Fantasy, Liszt’s Ballade No. 2 and Chopin’s 24 Preludes.

This year is the 30th anniversary of John Zorn’s “Cobra,” one of his improvisatory “Game Pieces,” in which musicians follow a set of cues and rules. Dither, an electric guitar quartet, presents an evening of Mr. Zorn’s Game Pieces, each involving different rules and tactics and resulting in unexpected, spontaneous performances.

This gallery’s fifth Picasso show organized by the artist’s biographer John Richardson is supposed to be a sweeping assessment of Picasso’s relationship to photography. But it’s a messy, fragmented affair, with a cluttered installation by the Broadway set designer David Korins. Viewers who can see past the slanted columns covered in blown-up photographs will, however, find some fantastic paintings, including the colorful Synthetic-Cubist canvas “Instruments de Musique sur un Guéridon,” the 1932 acrobatic nude “Le Repos,” and a marvelous series of 1939 portraits of Dora Maar in a strangely shaped red hat.

This thrilling exhibition of often unknown canvases suggests that Passlof raised her own brand of Caine working in the shadow of her teacher Willem de Kooning. In comparison, she painted more bluntly, with thicker paint and worried less about color and shape. Earliest and smallest may be best in this show, which any museum curator hoping to expand the story of Abstract Expressionism should see.

results.event_name: Susan Te Kahurangi King: ‘Drawings From Many Worlds’
results.web_description: This New Zealand artist   — the toast of this year’s Outsider Art Fair — reworks Looney Tunes characters like a rogue animator, abstracting, distorting and disassembling them in surreal and psychedelic landscapes. In one of the graphite drawings from this marvelous gallery debut, Sylvester the Cat is involved in a nasty-looking pileup of cartoon body parts. Later comes a Popeye head sprouting from the beak of the Road Runner, surrounded by ducks who are floating skyward in the manner of Tiepolo figures.

The debut of this talented young Danish artist consists of a wall of enticing, seemingly similar paintings on felt whose many subtle differences emerge with looking. Their shared motifs of multi-eyed rainbow and ambiguous orbs are visionary. Their physical presence conjures low-testosterone mediums like textiles, prints, peasant art and children’s book illustration. And two larger works in the office add variety.

results.event_name: Pablo Picasso: ‘Picasso and Jacqueline: The Evolution of Style’
results.web_description: This exhibition is fairly candid about the fact that its raven-haired, green-eyed subject (Picasso’s last companion and second wife, Jacqueline Roque) is not so much a muse as she is an art-historical Zelig. In paintings from the mid-1950s, she is a odalisque in Turkish costume, in tribute to Picasso’s great rival Matisse (who died in 1954) and to Delacroix, whose harem fantasy “Women of Algiers in Their Apartment” inspired a substantial and varied group of Picasso paintings and etchings. At other times, she appears to us as a prim Goya Madrileña in a black head scarf or as a calmly exhibitionist member of Manet’s luncheon party.

results.event_name: Pablo Picasso: ‘Picasso and Jacqueline: The Evolution of Style’
results.web_description: This exhibition is fairly candid about the fact that its raven-haired, green-eyed subject (Picasso’s last companion and second wife, Jacqueline Roque) is not so much a muse as she is an art-historical Zelig. In paintings from the mid-1950s, she is a odalisque in Turkish costume, in tribute to Picasso’s great rival Matisse (who died in 1954) and to Delacroix, whose harem fantasy “Women of Algiers in Their Apartment” inspired a substantial and varied group of Picasso paintings and etchings. At other times, she appears to us as a prim Goya Madrileña in a black head scarf or as a calmly exhibitionist member of Manet’s luncheon party.

results.event_name: Frick Collection: ‘Masterpieces From the Scottish National Gallery’
results.web_description: As it did last year with masterworks from the Mauritshuis, the Frick has welcomed 10 paintings from the Scottish National Gallery, in Edinburgh, home to a renowned collection of fine art from the Renaissance to the end of the 19th century. It’s a quieter sort of exhibition, exemplified by the under-the-radar entrance of Sargent’s “Lady Agnew of Lochnaw.” It’s also a rangier show, one that isn’t as identifiably Scottish as the Mauritshuis works were Dutch — even considering the commanding Sir Henry Raeburn portrait of a kilted Macdonell clan chief.

Ms. Rafferty’s latest show shies away from her usual celebrity subjects, and from figures in general, instead presenting utterly banal objects and interiors: a bathroom door, a wooden stool, a wall of subway tiles. At the same time, she is undertaking some wild experiments with materials like clear film and irregularly shaped pieces of transparent acrylic. The results are uncanny photo-objects, in the mold of Robert Heinecken.

The West Coast scores a major point against New York for stealing away Ballet Theater’s elegant, satisfying production of “The Nutcracker,” which will plant roots in sunny and snowless Southern California next year. Choreographed by the company’s artist in residence, Alexei Ratmansky, this version presents the oft-told story as a touching coming-of-age tale, complete with a touch of danger. (Most of it is still frolicsome fun, of course.) Don’t miss your last chance to see it in town.
results.venue_name: Howard Gilman Opera House, Brooklyn Academy of Music
results.date_time_description: Dec. 12, 16-19 at 7 p.m.; Dec. 13 at noon and 4:30 p.m.; Dec. 14 and 21 at 1 and 6 p.m.; Dec. 20 at 2 and 7 p.m.

results.web_description: Eugene Ionesco’s absurdist one-act play “The Lesson,” about the fraught relationship between professor and pupil, is the starting point of Annie-B Parson’s “The Snow Falls in the Winter.” Ahead of February performances at the Joyce, this company offers a sneak peak in its home studios as part of the NEW@Graham preview series. Ms. Parson introduces Wednesday’s showing.

Eugene Lang College is the liberal arts wing of the New School, among the many universities that call New York their campus. Lang Dance, the collective comprised of students pursuing dance studies at the college, presents its fall showcase in partnership with New York Live Arts, featuring new works by the veteran choreographers Jeanine Durning and Reggie Wilson, as well as dances created by the program’s own budding choreographers who studied with Sarah Michelson.
results.price: $9; free for New School students, faculty members and alumni

results.web_description: As part of Brink, a series dedicated to showcasing longer, investigatory works in progress in the later stages of development, Ms. Bowen presents “Eddie Brown,” a work examining embarrassment and the fine line between pride and shame. Lindsay Clark, who has been dancing for nearly three decades, contributes “Chosen Field,” which she says is the last dance she will make.
results.price: $15 at the door, $12 in advance, $10 for students

results.web_description: Most audiences see only a finished work onstage, but sometimes the raw material is equally compelling. Danspace Project’s DraftWork series gives viewers insight into works in process and lets them mingle and talk  with the artists at a casual post-showing reception. This week, Mr. Flomin and Mr. Masters offer their goods for public inspection.

results.event_name: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo
results.web_description: Since 1974, this all-male ballet troupe, affectionately known as the Trocks, has been celebrating and satirizing the cult of ballet with a delicious blend of cheeky humor and true reverence. The pokes come from a place of love — and knowledge. Its 40th anniversary Joyce season spans a spectrum of dance history, including excerpts from “La Naiade et Le Pecheur,” which dates to the mid-19th century, and smart parodies of classics, like “Swan Lake” and “Don Quixote.”
results.date_time_description: Dec. 16, 17, 23, 29 and 30 at 7:30 p.m.; Dec. 18-20, 26, 27, Jan. 2 and 3 at 8 p.m.;  Dec. 20, 21, 24, 27, 28, Jan. 3 and 4 at 3 p.m.; Dec. 31 at 5 p.m. No performances on Dec. 22, 25 or Jan. 1.

results.web_description: Many choreographers are given a chance to try out works in progress before an audience. The Chocolate Factory’s Throw series adds a twist: Artists get to pose three questions to audience members, who are instructed to respond simply and directly. For this round, audience members will help shape the work of Emily Gastineau and Billy Mullaney, Malcolm Low, Katie Rose McLaughlin, Dahlia Nayar, Tiny Little Band and Emily Wexler.

This company’s spin on the holiday tradition, “The Colonial Nutcracker,” situates Clara’s tale in Revolutionary War-era Yorktown. (Tchaikovsky’s famed score remains.) Though all Nutcrackers aim to please the little ones, this one is explicitly geared to children 5 to 10.
results.venue_name: Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts, Brooklyn College

results.web_description: Visiting from Philadelphia, where they’re a popular act, Magda San Millán and Chelsea Murphy bring their clever and crude feminist singer-songwriter-meets-TED Talk routine to New York. Mixing the deadpan chattiness of “Saturday Night Live” sketches like  “Delicious Dish” with the blunt sexual politics of Sarah Silverman, Magda & Chelsea’s “The Vulgar Early Works” will most likely be a self-empowering, socially critical, rambunctious romp.

In 1977, Ms. Kirkland, the famed ballerina, became America’s “Clara” when she danced the role in  Mikhail Baryshnikov’s televised production of “The Nutcracker.” But for her company’s version, the tale’s heroine is known as Marie (which is the case in some of the story’s many variations). Perhaps it’s a way to let her talented protégées come into their own, without having to dance in her shadow. Names aside, the traditional narrative and merriment remains.
results.venue_name: Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, Pace University
results.cross_street: between Park Row and Gold Street
results.date_time_description: Dec. 11-21: Thursdays and Fridays at 7:30 p.m., Saturdays at 2 and 7 p.m., Sundays at 2 p.m.

results.web_description: This ensemble’s version of “The Nutcracker” is set right here in New York, with choreography by a number of professional dancers, some current and former members of New York’s top ballet companies. “The Knickerbocker Suite,” as it’s called, makes stops at the Statue of Liberty, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Macy’s.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 12-21: Fridays and Saturdays at 7 p.m., Sundays at 3 p.m.

results.web_description: After having its premiere last year in Brooklyn and taking off on a national tour, “Bleed,” Tere O’Connor’s mesmerizing choreographic quilt, is back by popular demand for a four-performance encore. Over the course of two years, Mr. O’Connor created three distinct works then chopped them up and spliced them together to make a fourth that contains remnants of the originals but manages to find a riveting identity of its own.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 18-19 at 8 p.m.; Dec. 20 at 7 and 9:30 p.m.

results.event_name: Best Friends Animal Society’s Super Adoption Event
results.web_description: What could be a better holiday present than one that provides unconditional love? Best Friends Animal Society, an animal welfare organization, sponsors this event, which will offer more than 800 dogs, cats and rabbits that need good homes. (Adoption fees start as low as $25.) The festivities will also include music, food, a pet gift fair and a two-hour visit each day from Santa Claus (though no reindeer are up for adoption).
results.date_time_description: Dec. 12-13 from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Dec. 14 from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.

results.web_description: Baseball season may be over, but there’s still fun to be had at Citi Field. This first Winter Fest will bring Santa Claus and team mascots to the turf, along with cookie decorating, caroling, craft projects and face painting. There will even be baseballs: a variety of balls decorated and autographed by sports and cultural figures will be on display, to be auctioned off to benefit Toys for Tots.

So what’s a “pocket” production? It’s smaller and shorter, yes, but certainly not diminished. Presented by WindSync, a wind quintet whose members perform from memory and in costume, this presentation offers a whole new interactive and abridged version of the “Nutcracker” story, along with other holiday music.
results.venue_name: Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, Metropolitan Museum of Art

results.web_description: When you encounter a troupe with a name like this, you wonder what its members are pushing against. The apparent answer: theatrical boundaries and one another. Appearing at Symphony Space as part of the Just Kidding series, they aim to bring stories to life with acrobatics, illusions and bodily feats that are tough to execute but fun to watch.
results.venue_name: Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Symphony Space
results.price: $26; $16 for children; $22 and $14 for members; $65 for family four-packs, with the online code Familypass

results.web_description: Sculpture, painting, song and dance: However you might want to celebrate Hanukkah, the Jewish Museum will offer the creative means at this annual festival. A giant drop-in art workshop will present opportunities to turn found objects — spools, wood blocks, metal — into holiday sculptures; make light-inspired abstract paintings; and contribute to a huge communal menorah collage. From 1 to 3 p.m., the storyteller Jeff Hopkins will use live drawing to illuminate Hanukkah tales, and, at 2:30 p.m., Shirlala, a.k.a. Shira Kline, will perform a concert that brings the entire Hanukkah story to life. Brief gallery tours at 1:30 and 3 p.m., focused on the Hanukkah lamp collection, will round out the day.
results.price: free with museum admission: $15; $12 for 65+; $7.50 for students; free for 18 and under  and members

results.web_description: Don’t ever let toads drive cars. That’s one lesson you can derive from Kenneth Grahame’s children’s book “The Wind in the Willows,” but there are plenty more in this gentle tale of the adventures of the toad and his friends the mole, the badger and the river rat. The Pied Piper Children’s Theater of NYC is presenting Phil Greenland’s new musical adaptation of the story, which features children ages 5 through 12 in the cast and adolescents ages 12 through 18 in the crew.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 13-21. Saturdays at 3 and 7 p.m.; Sundays at 4 p.m.

results.event_name: Preservation Detectives: ‘When Mindy Saved Hanukkah’ Treasure Hunt
results.web_description: The Museum at Eldridge Street, the 1887 landmark synagogue where many Jewish immigrants worshiped, holds many stories within its walls. According to Eric A. Kimmel’s children’s book “When Mindy Saved Hanukkah” (Scholastic), it also harbors a miniature family there, the Kleins. In the story, these tiny humans need a candle for Hanukkah, and it’s up to Mindy, the enterprising daughter, to find it, the synagogue cat notwithstanding. In this program, part of the Preservation Detectives series, in which children 4 to 10 can view artifacts and sleuth their way into the past, participants will imitate Mindy in a scavenger hunt. They’ll also make little Klein-like figures and edible dreidels, and vote on the best way to spell Hanukkah.

results.event_name: Children’s Museum of Manhattan Muslim Arts Festival
results.web_description: December is filled with celebrations of Hanukkah and Christmas, but at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan, the Muslim world shines, too. This month its Muslim Arts Festival series highlights design and performance. On both days, the plans include a drop-in 3-D Mosque Architecture Experience (10 a.m. to noon), in which young visitors can investigate mosques worldwide, and a drop-in storytelling and dance session (12:30 p.m.) focused on the book “Rumi: Whirling Dervish,” by Demi. On Saturday only, the spoken-word artist Tahani Salah, a Palestinian-American, will offer poetry devoted to Muslim values, and on Sunday only, Dafer Tawil Music and Dance Ensemble will perform and teach Muslim dance, including traditional styles from Egypt. (Both of those programs, for ages 5 and older, require sign-up, first come first served.)
results.venue_name: Children's Museum of Manhattan, Tisch Building
results.price: Free with museum admission: $11; $7 for 65+; free for members and under 1.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 13-14 from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (Detailed schedule is on the website.)

results.web_description: Imagine “101 Dalmatians,” but with rabbits. In this new musical, based on a book series by Amber L. Spradlin, the title character, himself a pet, rescues 101 members of his species from a villain and finds them all a home for the holidays. He’s also involved in solving the disappearance of a Christmas star. This busy bunny and his friends (including a reindeer) are brought to the stage by the appropriately named Rabbit Hole Theatricks, whose production has a book and lyrics by Michael MacKenzie Wills and music by Alastair William King.

Her band may be called the Nightlights, but there’s nothing soporific about Joanie Leeds’s music. Ms. Leeds and her group will perform child-friendly, dance-worthy rock at this Hanukkah celebration at the Museum of Jewish Heritage, offering past hits and tunes from their latest album, “Good Egg.” Geared to ages 3 through 10, the festivities will also  include museum mini-tours and holiday crafts.
results.venue_name: Museum of Jewish Heritage -- A Living Memorial to the Holocaust
results.price: $10; $7 for ages 10 and under; $7 for members, and free for up to three members’ children ($5 for each additional child). Crafts are free with the purchase of tickets.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 14 at 2 p.m., with crafts from 1 to 4 p.m.

results.web_description: What does it take to warm an old man’s icy heart? In this case, about 12 adults and six children, a cast that also includes those all-important ghosts. They’re occupying the stage at Queens Theater in the Park in this world-premiere adaptation of Dickens’s tale by Emily Trask and Lenny Bonovez, both from the theater’s resident Titan Theater Company.
results.date_time_description: Dec. 12-21.  Fridays at 7:30 p..m. (there is also a preview on Dec. 12 at 2 p.m.); Saturdays at 2 and 7:30 p.m.; Sundays at 1 and 5 p.m.

results.event_name: Live From the NYPL: Joyce Carol Oates and Marlon James
results.web_description: On Friday, Ms. Oates, the prolific author of “Them,” “The Falls” and “We Were the Mulvaneys,” will deliver the annual Robert B. Silvers lecture, titled “Is the Uninspired Life Worth Living?” On Monday, Marlon James, author of the acclaimed “A Brief History of Seven Killings,” will talk with one of the authors he says inspired him to write, Salman Rushdie.
results.venue_name: Stephen A. Schwarzman Building, New York Public Library

results.event_name: Rufus Khan End of the Year Comedy Improvaganza
results.web_description: Rufus Khan, a short-form improv comedy team, hosts its monthly variety show with musical and long-form improv guests. (It’s sort of like the comedy series “Whose Line Is It Anyway?,” but set in a black box theater.) Audience members can almost certainly expect to be called on to participate  and maybe even end up onstage.

This filmmaker and raconteur presents his one-man show of perverse yuletide cheer, exploring holiday-related true crimes, the subject of gift giving and more. Mr. Waters will also take part in a meet and greet after the performance.
results.price: performance is sold out; meet-and-greet-only tickets are $55

results.event_name: The Upper East Side: ‘Joan Rivers’s Neighborhood’
results.web_description: The home of Joan Rivers, as well as the temple where her funeral was held, will be visited during this tour. Participants will also see the home of Eleanor and Franklin Roosevelt; the Frick Collection, the former residence of industrialist Henry Clay Frick; and the Explorer’s Club. It begins at 1 p.m. at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and East 62nd Street.

Hundreds of tuba players from around the country will perform during this annual holiday event at the Rink at Rockefeller Center. Christian Wilhjelm, a former conductor of the Goldman Band, will lead the musicians.
results.cross_street: between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas

results.event_name: Merchant’s House Museum Annual 19th-Century Holiday Party
results.web_description: This annual celebration, from 6 to 8 p.m., will include holiday music, scenes from the show “A Christmas Carol at the Merchant’s House,”  with the actor John Kevin Jones. There will also be tours of the house, a raffle and a gift sale.

results.event_name: Museum of American Finance: ‘The Self-Healing Depression of 1920-21: America’s Last Laissez-Faire Business Cycle Downturn’
results.web_description: James Grant, a financial journalist and historian, discusses his new book, “The Forgotten Depression: 1921: The Crash That Cured Itself.” The book explores the mystery of a short financial downturn that, despite certain policies from the government, ended after only 18 months. Mr. Grant will also sign books.

For those who think they’re on top of current events, here is a challenge for you. Presented by the Big Quiz Thing, this competition will pit teams of four to six people against one another. The questions will concern  the people and events in the news over the past year; the prizes include  theater tickets and gift certificates. Teams can still register for the event.

This exhibition, opening on Sunday, features two dozen small, glowing robots that have been programmed to communicate with one another and react to people’s movements, either following them or zooming away. In addition to the fun, the show will feature material that explains the simple mathematical rules behind swarm technology.
results.price: $15, $9 for students, children and 65+, free for toddlers

results.event_name: ‘Cosby, Pryor, and the Biography of African-American Comedy’
results.web_description: The writers Mark Whitaker (“Cosby: His Life and Times”) and Scott Saul (“Becoming Richard Pryor”) will take part in this free discussion, which will also focus on the difficulties of writing biographies. In his review of Mr. Whitaker’s Bill Cosby biography for The New York Times, Dwight Garner wrote, “This book’s greatest omission, as others have pointed out, is its total avoidance of the sexual abuse allegations that have dogged Mr. Cosby.” Gary Giddins, a jazz critic and author, and Mel Watkins, a former editor in The New York Times Book Review and author of several books on comedy, including “On the Real Side: A History of African-American Comedy From Slavery to Chris Rock,” will also take part. Reservations, which are suggested, can be made at biography@gc.cuny.edu.

Neil Gaiman joins Hayley Campbell in a discussion of her new book, “The Art of Neil Gaiman,” about the author’s creative life. Mr. Gaiman’s oeuvre includes novels, comics, film and TV, and Ms. Campbell’s illustrated book is an authorized account of his life and work. Mr. Gaiman and Ms. Campbell will sign books after the event.
results.price: purchase of book required for entry
